pros:
There was very good access to training and further education. There were good progression opportunities, with well-defined paths for moving into more senior roles (However you had to wait x amount of months before you could progress again). You also get to work alongside some very competent and fun colleagues.

Compensation wasn't great but they did have fantastic benefits including health insurance and generous pension contributions.
cons:
When I was there the company was making a lot of structural changes which meant day-to-day work was quite disorganized. There were so many acquisitions it was hard to fully grasp what products did and how to position them. They had a big hiring push so everyone's territories were squeezed and sales targets for most were often unrealistic. Pay scales and progression were very rigid so you had to follow the well-beaten path rather than having options open up if you were performing well.

review_title: The long haul at Oracle and lessons learned.
pros: Tools Team can lead to interesting work sometimes. Good people. Good stepping stone job.
cons:
Hired at Market value but you fall behind and there is no reasonable path to catch up. Management (all the way up to my VP) were powerless and could do nothing to help even if they wanted to. I calculated my pay deficit over 21 years, assuming I was hired at market value, and compared what I could have made if I stayed at market value (for example, by jumping companies as soon as I fell behind) vs. what I actually made at Oracle. 21 years of starting at market that diminished to a 38% of market value resulted in a heart-breaking $1.8 million loss in pay. A hard lesson to learn.

Long periods of stagnation in title/role, even when you perform at a higher level for years. I've been a PMTS for 14 years even though I've been performing at the next level the last 5-6 years.

I averaged 12-16 hour days over 21 years.
Advice to Management
Value employees over profit. In this culture, employee loyalty is worthless. When an employee is making 38% of what you hire new people doing the same work to do, and you tell the person that the only (mildly possible) way to get up to market pay is to show a competing offer from a different company, there is something very wrong with your system. I don't know any employee at Oracle that would stay after getting a competing offer at market value (just to fall behind again as soon as market value exceeds your current pay).

review_title: All the good and the bad
pros:
- Promotes Healthy office culture
- A lot how you work depends on your Manager. Everything is good until your manager is able to handle people skills and technical skills. If the manager is incompetent, everything else falls apart.
- Good Learning and growth
- Some projects follow strict Hierarchical Management and with some you can just walk in and discuss your feedback, expectations and issues face to face.
- Highly motivates you to grow your career and leadership skills.
- Establish a trust relationship with peers, a friendly environment with continuous Team building activities.
cons:
- Top Management decisions are not transparent to team members.
- Project may shutdown at any time without prior notice or indication even though they have a roadmap for two years to come.
- Unpredictable Business growth. 
- Lack in the use of latest technology and frameworks.

review_title: good remote work, but a lot of management layers who don't do very much
pros:
- good remote work from home
- stable environment
- easy to standout (if you just work a little harder, you are a rockstar)
- competitive compensation and good benefits
cons:
- a lot of management tiers with majority not doing anything
- management like to hear themselves talk, but don't do very much
- everyone is jockeying for credit; managers take credit for team members
- a lot of meetings with a lot of talking but no action
- slow to take action; very slow organization
- people like their processes; are not open to new ideas ("don't break it if it is not broken")
- a lot of people "phoning it in"
Advice to Management
- get rid of most management layers (why are there 3-4 layers of VPs?)
- promote/hire from the outside... too much Oracle think made by people who like to phone it in.

review_title: Good fun, bad for work ethic
cons:
ltant in Dublin, Dublin
Recommend
CEO Approval
Business Outlook
Pros
Decent pay for starting out, lots of young people so it was like being in college. Probably the most fun place I will ever work.
Cons
Their strategy was poor. I spent 3 years across 4 roles in Oracle and the real upper management thought you could sell complex financial systems that are business critical and can take a couple of years to migrate to by cold calling CFOs of 400M+ annual revenue. They did go through a big change after I left so maybe this has been fixed.
Advice to Management
Stop focusing solely on KPIs. For almost all of us, the days became a box ticking exercise to keep management off our backs. A lot of people spent many years working there without selling anything, just ticking boxes and getting more and more depressed.

review_title: Review of Oracle from a Millenial
pros:
-have good mentor and coworkers
-lots of opportunities for networking and internally transferring
-learn a lot about the technology
-unlimited pto
-good cicd pipeline and standard development cycle
-was able to internally transfer and get a better base salary
-good benefits and stock
-depending on your team, it could be a hit or miss
cons:
-remote work gets lonely, no communication besides work with coworkers
-pay isn't as competitive as other places
-work/life balance is horrible. even though unlimited pto, upper management pressures to reach endless deadlines
-oncall policy makes me cry. 24/7 availability, 15 minute acknowledgement and 2 hour resolving the issue/outage. if you're primary, it's hellish depending on your team
-upper management exerts anger and does not give constructive criticism in both departments I was in 
-lots of harassment goes unnoticed since no one wants to bring it up
Advice to Management
more constructive criticism and do not push and put into 1-1 calls in order to pressure the employee to meet deadline. sometimes, it's out of the employee's control, like peer reviews

review_title: Speaking for OFSS. A company equally good and bad.
pros:
Brand value definitely is the top pro(for this reason alone you can take OFSS over other noname company paying say 1-2 lakh more).
If you are lucky you might get good work(spring-boot/microservices).
what they quote is what you get in hand.
Good worklife balance especially for developers.
Job security. Perfect company for retirement.
Overtime pay is there.
Good people mostly.
cons:
The chance that you will end up with legacy software written in PL/SQL. I did. (If that is the case then use your brand value and skills to get out within a year or so, or if you plan on staying do change your team).
Pay is not competitive, even if you compare with Oracle India, OFSS in my time payed around 2-3 lakhs lesser, though if you are from IIT you can get packages above 15 lpa. For developers bonus is not timely, stocks are not given though you can opt for oracle ESPP. Consultants get timely bonus but their base pay is lesser. Also consultants have more work load.
I had even heard of dry promotions, you get promoted without a hike. One guy I knew was also in same position for 5 years, higher management was not ready for his promotion due to his role being lesser even though he was a developer.
Advice to Management
Pay needs to be more competitive else people will leave. Make OFSS pay at least on par with Oracle India pay. Please try to give timely hikes and bonuses.

review_title: Negotiate your salary from the start.
pros: Excellent benefits. Vision insurance in particular is top notch. Some managers are great at their jobs, if you're fortunate to be on their team. The work/life balance is also nice if you're not in a DM role.
cons:
Pay is average when you start and insulting as time goes on. Negotiate as much as you can when getting hired on because you won't see too much beyond that. There are no cost of living increases, no bonuses, no work from home stipend.
Advice to Management
Pay your tenured people better. There is no reason why a new hire is making nearly 30k more a year than an employee with the same job title who was hired several years prior. Ultimately I believe this is why people leave. It's not a secret that new hire pay increases regularly while current employee pay is stagnant.

Recommend
CEO Approval
Business Outlook

A closed set of techs and tools are used which is specific to Oracle only.

review_title: My review after almost 20 years in Oracle. Read before applying or accepting an offer.
pros: Money, work life balance, great "part-time" job, benefits.
cons:
Cons
Thanks for taking the time to read my review. I have been with Oracle for over a decade. I write this to give potential candidates a real look into the company. Someone who has been with the company 12-24 months may not have a very wide view since you are required to stay in a position for a year and people rarely leave their area. I have worked in several different areas in my time at the company. I came on as part of an acquisition. You will see folks who give good ratings and approve of the CEO, but it’s really good to check to see how long they’ve been there as Oracle will not show all their cards up front. That typically doesn’t happen until you’re in there a few years. Good Luck! 

Training & Development – In my almost 20 years here, I have never witnessed any dedicated employee development. Part of management's job is to develop their employees, but that is completely non-existent. In the Global Business Units (GBU's) it's even worse. Oracle's latest “employee development” program literally has employees filling out word docs about their goals and such. Basically what people did in 1999. As for actual training, for the courses someone might need to improve in their jobs or become more skills, Oracle will charge you thousands of dollars to take them. In my years here, I had one training course that my unit paid for. With the advent of the cloud, you are able to get access to subscription learning. These are setup as videos for the most part, so you're just watching powerpoint slides go by and once you're done, there's no real reinforcement. In my time here I have not watched one person be developed from a hire to employee to management. Usually in a decade you would have one or two examples of progression. 

Salaries & Raises – I know of a person who was recently asked to transfer teams, but they originally thought it was a promotion and then told it was not. The person transferred teams and then was asked to apply for the position. The departments are basically doing anything underhanded they can to save money and they do not care if people leave. People are leaving my unit in droves. There is a ton of managers who are just flat out leading people on. And as many have mentioned here, the lowest in the industry. If you are considering this company as a place of employment, negotiate as high as you can. In our unit of thousands of people, there have been people who have not even gotten a cost of living raise in 5-10 years. Managers, as well as directors, are pretty spineless and won’t stick up for anyone. I have watched people get lied to about money, I have watched colleagues be sold one job and think they were getting their “level” raise only for the manager to remove the job and create another job that was a lateral move. You are around some really scummy low down people. This is not like the big and successful tech companies. This is basically the lowest end of tech. With that being said, you need to do something remarkable to get any type of raise. You need to really beat everyone on your team and basically be perfect for 12 months. And even then, quite the stretch. And they’ll tell you, “that’s all we could get from management. Be happy you got anything at all.” I have heard directly from someone who was protected that when they contacted HR about the “promotion” that actually had them making less money, the HR person said, “you should just be happy you got a promotion.” Management that are friends with other managers will also have an impact on those things. I have gotten raises in my time here, but with salaries being so low, it's not a lot. As mentioned before, if you get in via an acquisition, you could get a nice bump from what you were making, but that's up for negotiation between Oracle and the old company. 

Work-Life Balance – The single reason I have heard anyone stays here is because they can work from home and get their work done in 4-5 hours a day. That's really the biggest benefit of the company and don't think anyone would argue. 

Management – Lead with talent and qualifications and not who your buddy was at a partner/acquisition/high school/pre school. There are many thick and useless layers of management. Many of them with very little technology and or real IT experience. When Oracle acquires smaller companies, if they are under the GBU framework, the company can basically say, a janitor is now a Senior Director and no questions are asked. I have watched scores of people come in that way and just leapfrog over people who have been in the unit for decades. It's even more embarrassing when the people who have been there basically know 10 times more about everything and the new member of management just sits around being social and not really contributing. I've also never seen the same members of management sit in the same exact positions for decades. These managers stay in office longer than presidents. Their attitudes are smug and many are downright hated by their team members. The thing is, you work in a tech company and you should know the buzz words or at least know what they mean. I have been in meetings where a director actually said to someone two levels below them that, “that's not their job to know how to do this or that...that's on you to know...” At Oracle, as opposed to many other companies I have worked at, to be in management, you do not need to have been good at any one particular job or the jobs of your team. It is truly amazing. My thought is they stay because no companies really want them. 

The Cloud – applications on the cloud were deployed with very little strategy or education to the employees. They will never catch the other tech companies that are staffed with better talent and management. Management wants to tout the cloud as being a success, but it's basically because customers are basically strong-armed into going to it and they are flat out lied to when speaking about the overall performance of the cloud. There is also a mentality among management and long time employees that Oracle is better than Amazon. Anyone who knows the tech sector right now, knows that's laughable. At Oracle, they can't even speak about their competition because they're getting beaten so bad. What's worse is that there are smaller companies that are now coming up that have better products, better platforms, cheaper price and less problems.
Advice to Management
- Start being moral and ethical. It's 2021 and social media is huge. There are forums that are filled with anonymous reviews of Oracle and even people by name who work there. Remember your legacy are your people. 
- Turnover all levels of management. Managers should not be in the same positions for decades as it gives a perception of stagnation. If they can't do the job of the people they manage, they don't deserve to be manager. 
- Educate sales people on what they're actually selling prior to letting them sell. Make sales aware of what other groups are doing. 
- Develop and promote the people who strive to learn and grow instead of people who come in the back door who haven't proven themselves to anyone. 
- Going to have to increase salaries to keep top talent to compete with the real winners in tech space.
- Things need to change!!

review_title: Poor Management, Abysmal Training, No Support
pros: Pay and benefits are decent, Unlimited Sick Time, Decent vacation/holiday, No overtime. there are some great people here who are really kind and helpful.
cons:
There were people who told me they didn't dare to use their sick time because their manager would get so upset. Sometimes overtime is needed but even then they won't approve it unless it is a critical situation, and what you and I consider critical and what the customers consider critical usually doesn't fit the criteria. The situation has to be at catastrophic levels before such things are approved. 

The training really is terrible. I was told by my friend not to worry about it, that 'you will learn your job when you do your job'. Not even that was true. Everyone I knew was frustrated, with few exceptions. I asked one gal how she knew what she was doing, as she was helping me, and she said she had a degree in databases. Those that know what they are doing were spread so thin.

From what I saw they really don't care about their customers. I could spend an hour writing up a bug and then another hour going over it with my mentor. He knew what he was doing, but told me, yeah, they're still going to ____ and say it's not good enough. That was typical. Once in a meeting, two weeks after I had filed a bug, the developer discussed it with me and I had to explain to him what was wrong and why it was important to the customer. All of this I had written in the bug but he hadn't even read it. I also asked him for an ETA on a bug and he never replied. I asked in the bug, I asked by email, he just ghosted me. I even sent a message to his manager. No luck. I was floored by the lack of concern for a customer, especially as we went through five one hour sessions to train us to bend over backwards for them. On top of this, I eventually found an ETA listed in the bug and told the customer, and the developer chastised me very sternly for doing this. I tried to ask him how I was supposed to talk to him and get an ETA and he avoided the question by chastising me more - basically gaslighting me for trying to help a customer. 

So much of the documentation is incomplete. If you've never used the system before it's impossible to navigate from the instructions given. So much of my time was wasted trying to accomplish step 3 in a list of directions when it should have been step 4 or 5. At that there were very few people I could ask questions of. My manager encouraged my mentor to shut me out unless it was our scheduled call. She told me I was expected to train myself. To me there is no excuse for this. Even with customizations, the documentation should be at or near complete, in many cases it was nonexistent and sometimes google was better than our knowledge base. It was so frustrated because I went in ready to work hard and learn, and help customers. I have been a rock star at this type of work in other positions but with no support I was just frustrated. I tried to document whatever I could so others could learn, but I could only learn what others were willing to teach me, or what I could glean from other SRs and incomplete documentation. Everyone is spread so thin - and then they laid a bunch of us off because we only had 11 service requests at a time. A lot of the verbiage in the documentation was also very hard to read because Oracle hires a lot of non-native speakers, so adding that into having it incomplete just added to my frustration, but the biggest shock to me was the attitude towards the customers. I told a senior engineer that a situation was embarrassing and he told me that if I was embarrassed about that I would be embarrassed all the time. Well, yes, I was until I just had to take the 'not my circus, not my monkeys' approach. But I would have loved to be able to take some ownership and have that matter. That's what I set out to do but was thwarted at every turn. Try as I might, I couldn't learn much, couldn't change much and couldn't help much, and that was demoralizing as I've always prided myself on having the customer's back, as well of that of my teammates, but at Oracle, nobody had mine. 

I'll just mention too that having to drive into the office and getting sick because others were sick was silly. Most of the people I needed to interact with were in other offices across the country, so I was just sitting there with people who couldn't help me.

Another frustration was that a manager there would always look at me like I was disgusting if I didn't wear makeup. If I had dressed up and looked gorgeous she was fine but if I wasn't, she would make a face like I had just puked or something. It was really humiliating. 

My manager admitted that she can be a _____ sometimes, like she was not ashamed of it. Unfortunately I was on the receiving end of that and HR knows all about it. They tried to put the blame on me, but I helped them see reason, at least enough that while they said they wanted to continue our discussions, they never scheduled another meeting.

I've since heard that my team was very overloaded and many of them have left, which is a shame because it takes 3-4 years for a person to get comfortable, from what I am told. 

They also said one of senior management was asking if they were all helping each other to get their queues down. I think most people can understand that if each rep has 96 service requests at any given time, helping each other is going to do little to reduce that number. If one person has that many, others can help bring it down by sacrificing some work on their own queues, but when it's everyone, it seems pretty juvenile for someone to suggest such a thing, and it makes me think that guy obviously isn't being paid the big bucks because he earned his position. It's their own fault for laying off a bunch of people. There was plenty of work, they need lots of documentation and I was more than willing to do that as much as I could and to update the current documentation. I had hoped when I started and saw the state the documentation was in, that I could update it and make it easy for anyone to follow, but that soon became a pipe dream. I wrote lots of documents, but not near as many as I could have if someone had been willing to train me and if my teammates had not been stretched so thin. Definitely did not anticipate being laid off under these circumstances.

Also about the developers - even my manager said that the developers my team was working with had bad attitudes and were some of the worst she's seen at Oracle.

One more example, everyone talked in generalities. Go tell the customer to do this. In one case a senior engineer told me that and I said okay, I don't know how to do that, I can't find instructions, can you give me navigation steps? He ghosted me. I tried to ask again, still nothing, not ever. Sure enough the customer asked for navigation steps and berated me for not giving them in the first place, but there was nothing I could do. I'm told the customer should have known, but that makes me feel pretty silly asking them to do something I can't. I often learned things by watching the customers during zoom calls, they knew more than I did. So embarrassing.
Advice to Management
Don't tell your customers you really care about them unless everyone internally (especially the developers) really do. I was amazed to see that campaign roll out, then we had the training, and the developers never showed any change in attitude - I wonder if they had that training at all. If they did it did no good.

pros: I had a great team, met some lovely people, I enjoyed the flexibility to work from home, and I did have good work-life balance whilst working at Oracle.
cons:
Zero transparency, upper management does not know what they are doing, extremely decentralized and fragmented with multiple teams competing to achieve the same thing and not willing to collaborate or share information. Huge lack of transparency with management changes and business objective changes. They will not tell you anything until the end and completely derail or scrape projects you've spent weeks or months working on. You do not see the results of work. They will change your title (a change in work level but not in salary) and tell you that you're going to get a promotion to reflect this change, but will delay to no end. They will convince you they need you and then will let you go at a moment's notice. Absolutely horrific management system. They do not care, there's no motivating factor, there are few team building activities or opportunities, the culture is very "big red corporate machine" with absolutely zero concern for people who have worked for them for years. Felt demotivated, deflated, underpaid, unappreciated, and had to fight to be given work and put on projects despite delivering quality work repeatedly (from feedback). Very little help with actual career development, quite stagnant.
Advice to Management
Be open, and transparent. Develop trust and collaborate. You're working for the same company, stop trying to compete doing the same exact thing and wasting resources. Do not give employees false information and hope and then cut them off. Listen and respond. Foster team building activities. Value employees.

review_title: A great place to build and sustain your career
pros:
Oracle has built/ acquired market-leading products and services so it's a cash-rich company. Many people have made good money, especially at Cloud division. 
Work-life balance is very good with some pressure during releases, but that's common across the software industry.
cons:
Oracle India is different from overall Oracle and is highly dependent on Oracle US for directions and hence the hierarchy is not very successful.
There's a huge salary difference at the same level for cloud and application employees, which is not good for growth and attrition is high in both areas.
There was no one-off allowance for home setup which was given across a lot of other companies.
The other departments like admin, HR, etc. are lull and have a very little say in your work-life which might be good, but it takes long time to get stuff done.
Be the first to find this review helpful

review_title: Decent starting role and atmosphere for recent grads, but don't expect to take away many transferrable hard skills.
cons:
ltant in Austin, TX
Recommend
CEO Approval
Business Outlook
Pros
The office atmosphere for this role is very lively and energetic for recent college grads, most of your colleagues will be around the same age as you, making it a smooth transition into working life. The work isn't hard and you get a great work/life balance.
Cons
With any sales role, your soft communication skills will be developed in this role but it's very hard to transition laterally or get promoted into anything even slightly more technical or non-sales. They don't equip you with any valuable technical skills that you can eventually transfer over or grow with.
Advice to Management
Encourage your reports to expand their skill-sets into things that actually technically challenge themselves and stop trying to convince them that every other role out there is "basically the same thing as sales."

pros: I love working here. Lots of tools and resources at our disposal. It's exciting having the opportunity to work for such a large company, which means there are lots of opportunities for movement within.
cons:
No annual salary increases (tied to performance or even small cost of living increases). Kind of a bummer, and honestly pretty surprising when I started. There is also no direct path to grow within your team. I love what I do, but when a Senior level team member left, it seemed to open a spot for advancement (for myself or another member of my team). However, we were informed that since the role wouldn't change all that much from what we do now, Oracle does not provide title changes/promotions within the same team (thought process being it's kind of a lateral move, increased compensation without any real increase in responsibilities). I don't want to have to change teams each time I want to progress in my career.
Advice to Management
Find ways to encourage growth and career progression w/o forcing ICs to have to move to other teams. Sometimes, all we want is a little recognition for longevity, and that will translate into more confidence and better performance.

review_title: Cozy place if you are in your late 40s
pros:
Cozy place, nobody stresses you too much
Flexible working hours
Yearly bonus if you achieve your goals (100 RSUs)
Everyone is kind and friendly
Nobody get's upset if you screw up (tomorrow is also a day)
cons:
Salary doesn't increase in time
You don't get promotions unless somebody leaves
Goals are very general and designed to be debatable
Everybody is in their late 50s so don't expect changes to come to the team
They work with established methodologies and are not open to new
Expect long hors when big projects are about to launch (12+ hours per day, for 2-4 weeks, at least 2 times per year)
Advice to Management
Recognize people's achievements otherwise, good employees will leave and only the low performers will stay. 
You want to built a giant company? Hire people that are smarter than you. 
Want to see the company fall? Then hire people that make you feel good about yourself but are also lazy and don't perform.

review_title: Been a great place for me, might not be for everybody
pros: Hard work is well rewarded especially via stock for development org. The benefits are excellent and comprehensive. There’s plenty of opportunity to learn and apply your skills. With a great immediate manager and enough buffer from the ones that manage by f-bombs, it’s a great environment.
cons:
Management can slow things down and tend to get in the way. Many upper level managers/vps clearly haven’t taken the required courses on harassment and micro aggressions (if they have, they’ve learned little). While stock awards are generous to top performers, bonus and raise rounds in recent years pale in comparison to 90s-early 2000/“s. 

The company is overloaded with way too many “customer-care” type people that contribute little but hound those actually doing work for continual status updates. These roles are duplicated across various divisions which makes it even worse. Dealing with these people is by far the most miserable part of the job for me. I’m pretty sure bonuses and raises would still be plentiful if these people weren’t consuming so much payroll.
Advice to Management
Abide by the anti harassment (verbal) and other compliance training the rest of us do. Get rid of the bloated csm, customer care folks.

review_title: Great start but depends where you land. Product and management placement can be a crapshoot.
pros:
Really great 1st job to have on a resumé out of school. Allowed early advancement opportunities to field rep within 5 years. 

My original manager and organization was great.
cons:
Change. The company is constantly changing organizational strategy and leadership as they reorient to the cloud. Had 4 VPs in 5 years. Mark Hura (Cloud Tech SVP) seems to have a handle on issues and shortcomings.

Lack of goodwill. Years of mistreating customers from shady reps and lack of true support can be difficult to overcome.

Operates as 9 separate companies. Your success and experience solely relies on management and what product you sell. ERP and apps (NetSuite) are market leaders while OCI is last in the market with a lot to overcome.
Advice to Management
Don't prioritize short term sales goals for long term customer goodwill, that has changed somewhat but it might be too late.

Have seen managers with high attrition, immoral sales tactics, and poor management skills not only stick around but get promoted! The old notorious Oracle sales tactics have eroded customer trust and still persist with tenured leaders and managers. Some senior leaders still operate with intimidation and immoral sales tactics (i.e if customer isn't talking to us, audit them).

review_title: Smarten Up or Prepare to Continue to Loose Talent
pros: A ton of flexibility in one’s work schedule and great benefits are reasons for why employees stay here for long periods of time.
cons:
Raises are extremely rare. Be prepared to make your starting salary the entirety of your Oracle career. Career path progression is extremely difficult here. Employee satisfaction is at an all time low in the Oracle Advertising org. Nepotism runs rampant and blackballing occurs frequently if you don’t fall in line. Huge lack of diversity.
Advice to Management
Invest in keeping top talent. Dedicate resources, time and money into employee satisfaction. Turnover is so high because employees are miserable and top performers are not compensated or awarded appropriately. On the flip side, there is no accountability when employees under perform consistently for years. Focus needs to be put on improving the toxic culture within the Oracle Advertising org.

Repor

pros:
Remote work (probably forever).
Ability to do almost nothing without anyone noticing it.
cons:
Impossible to grow for senior developers. There were nothing I could do to grow. Even direct question about it to a manager was left without a response. As a result when you ask for salary raise you need to "justify" it. Managers did nothing to keep me (and some other developers/testers) when they saw we were about to leave.
I have very big doubts a quality and consequences in one of the projects. Many things there were done to achieve very short terms goals sacrificing long term goals. From technology perspective it was very easy development (so, will not give anyone real benefits in a CV).
The culture is also broken (it can be different in other teams). Once I directly asked my team members not to share some information to management but at the end it was shared.
Management is not able to change many things that were asked by a team. Most of them came after sprint retrospectives. So, be prepared to stay alone with that.
Promotions from developers or QAs to managers looked very strange. Many team members were unsatisfied with people who was promoted and who wasn't.
Advice to Management
Show your people that they are important, listen to them. Be ready to change many things if it asked.

review_title: Stable company with good benefits; hard to advance; average pay and inconsistent raise structure
pros: Oracle has been doing well for a while, so the culture in my division has been fairly positive and healthy the whole time I've been there. There are office politics at any job, but it doesn't tend to get in the way of a functioning organization. The benefits are also good - medical, dental, vision, vacation, holidays. These things can always be better, but I think most people are happy with what is offered. In my division of Oracle, everyone has an unlimited PTO setup, and for the most part management has been accommodating and encouraging in getting people to take regular time off. Getting a good manager is always a toss up, but I've been lucky to have been led by multiple experienced, motivated managers who I actually felt cared for my well being and work-life balance.
cons:
Oracle is a huge company, so it is easy to get lost in the shuffle of things. This makes it difficult to standout, and even more difficult to advance in any significant manner. Even when the company does well (and it has for the past few years), the pay is probably more competitive elsewhere. There are no bonuses, and the schedule for raises is nonexistent. Sometimes it is yearly, one time it was about 2.5 years, and apparently your raise has no tie to company performance. I have stayed because I am still advancing, I'm doing something I'm interested in, I'm getting paid fairly for it, and Oracle looks good on a resume for when I do decide to move on. Overall, I realize I am as expendable as anyone else at Oracle, but it really comes down to your more immediate group and whether that is being run the right way. There are lots of middle managers here, so hope you get lucky and get one that cares about you.
Advice to Management
Figure out and communicate a consistent, regular raise scheme. Inconsistent/nonexistent raises and promotions - for people who are totally deserving of them - are going to cause people to quit.
Be the first to find this review helpful

4. Being a famous and big IT organisation, internally the management cultivate bad culture and alot of politicking. Its a toxic place to work in.
5. Besides bad leadership and management, the internal process is very complicating and inconvenience. A new employee has to set up their own laptop, account, profile etc referring to a document on how to set up their own machine. Bad IT support, for an IT company. 
6. Unfortunately Mr. Larry Ellison and Ms. Safra Catz do not realised the hardship the employees suffer and face, especially during the pandemic. While everybody is working from home, there are no consideration of any 'hardship allowance' given to the employees. 
7. If one doesn't mind working for a reputable IT company who doesn't reward/recognised or give out bonus/increment, by all means, join ORACLE CORPORATION.
Advice to Management
Mr. Ellison should consider to revamp the entire LEADERSHIP TEAM, starting from Ms. Safra Catz.

review_title: Joining OCI vs being acquired makes all the difference
pros:
* Great technology (even if they discourage employee dogfooding)
* IF you are being hired by Oracle, the starting pay is well-above-average AND you can even negotiate your IC level as part of the hiring process
* OCI makes some attempts at Internet culture (free snacks including limited fresh fruit)
* The education benefit is above-average though it won't pay for your entire degree. If you are on a greenfield project then you will have time to pursue this.
cons:
* IF you are acquired by Oracle (or will be):
** Your out of pocket insurance costs will go way up
** You will be put on-call without additional compensation.
** You will spend years watching your pay scale fall behind the industry... New positions will have a "pay range" and you will be underwater.
** You will be given false promises that your project won't be cancelled. They don't mean to lie.
** Technical debt will grow EXPONENTIALLY. Expect a brain drain, additional processes so that all tasks take longer to do. Then "unfunded mandates" (like: "migrate everything from GH to BB") will cause all the Chef and Ansible to break... and your short term workarounds will become permanent extra work.
** Any work you want to do to improve supporting the produce will need approval. If you get paged at 4AM twice a month, but there's no customer impact, then you are not allowed to fix the issue... even if you promised to put in extra hours to do so. That will just be viewed you're not putting in enough time for the prescribed tasks.

If you are on a legacy project, you will be promised you won't be fired BUT NOT in writing. They will not find a place for you (see the Solaris folks for example). You will be allowed to re-apply for any open job however since your skill set atrophied you won't likely qualify and you will feel out of time applying somewhere else. 

Basically you want to leave Oracle BEFORE change of control. That way if you decide to come back, you don't need to wait the full 2 years that other employees must wait.

Oh, if you're not acquired, I'd recommend a 24-month tour.
Advice to Management
None. Seriously. Management knows about problems way before they get to the courts. There is so much engineer attrition the way the company survives is by rewarding the bloated management class.
Be the first to find this review helpful
Helpful

review_title: Don't fall for fake reviews on glassdoor
pros: None. Writing five words because glassdoor doesn't allow to post.
cons:
1. Worst company to work for. Even TCS/Infosys/Cognizant/Capgemini have better compensation and increments.
2. Extremely poor growth.
3. Company has policy of external first.
4. Fresh college graduates have double the compensation of existing employees.
5. Too much politics.
6. Outdated technology is used.
7. Paid food. Feels like school where lunchboxes can be seen all around during lunch break.
8. Inverse Seniority (More Experienced: Less compensation, Less Experienced: More Compensation)
9. Windows workstations only/Macbooks not an option for employees.
10. Highly recommended for 50+ age people looking for retirement company

All the good reviews posted on glassdoor are there because company told employees to post and share screenshot of it. Company is not getting good employees. Even offer letters are getting returned.

They don't listen to advice so not use of giving one.

pros: Great people and community culture. They adapted to a fully remote working environment exceptionally well. Decent pay for an entry level job. You will learn A TON about how to find success in sales. The sales org is growing leaps and bounds and there is a lot of opportunity for advancement.
cons:
Sales org structure changes all the time and without warning. Territories change often which is a symptom of growth but it can be stressful when it seems to happen so suddenly. Hours are supposed to be 8:30-5:30 but realistically if you want to hit quota and have success you will find yourself working extra hours. There is rarely an opportunity to earn overtime pay, although I have in the past on occasion
The job can be tedious after a while and burnout is likely. It’s good to keep in mind that the entry level program leads to better opportunities down the line.
Be the first to find this review helpful

pros:
Good benefits, 3 medical seppliers to choose from, WFH all throughout the pandemic,
Supportive manager (for my team)
cons:
Salary cannot be increased over time in my LOB (OU). Through transfer the increase is very small. Must leave Oracle for at least a year to be able to renegociate.
Advice to Management
Consider more than number and statistics when deciding the new LOB directions. Throughout my years at Oracle I have seen transitions that were in fact failures in the long team. 2-3 year preparations for a change that was deemed useless close to the end of the process. Elimination of entire teams not based on performance, but the overall cost to Oracle. Even though Oracle seems to lead segments of the markets it operates in for consecutive years, the quality of the Support offered is decreasing - according to customers.

pros:
Best job I’ve ever had because of the work life balance. If you have stuff to do or need to take off management is very understanding and doesn’t ask any questions. Culture is great.
The benefits are good and start day 1.
cons:
Very hard to get raises and promotions in Deal Management. For example there are people were hired on entry level and remain entry level 5-6 years later. There are people who have taken lateral move “promotions” with the promise of a promotion at a TBD time.
Advice to Management
Give more raises and promotions, bring employee salaries up to the standard cost of living. There’s nothing more demotivating than finding out people hired after you are being paid more too. Find a way to account for all of this in a budget.

review_title: Below average industry pay, horrible culture, but above average benefits
pros:
-The benefits are the best I've ever had, with extremely affordable health care, free dental and vision (depending on your plan).
-Seems to be an extremely stable place to work so far
cons:
-Below average pay
-Employee Stock Program is a joke (95% of the purchase price, the industry standard is 85%)
-No bonus
-No raises (unless you're willing to start working off of the clock)
 -Seriously, I've always been a top performer at every place I've ever worked, going above and beyond, but every year I've been here Oracle has rated me as "Meets Expectations". I asked my manager about this and he implied that it was because I didn't sacrifice enough of my personal time to help out the company. I'm sorry, but I negotiated this as an hourly job. If you're not approving overtime, then I'm comping my hours.

-Culture. I'll admit that it has gotten a bit better, but you can tell management is seething beneath their smiles. I've seen and heard racist, sexist, and misogynistic acts. I haven't reported them personally, because Oracle literally states in its compliance videos that it can't guarantee any protection for whistle-blowers, and my position in the company makes it impossible to file an anonymous complaint. That said, I've had several co-workers leave and, according to them, they told HR during their exit interviews of what they experienced, and I haven't heard of any repercussions.

-SLT likes to make smarmy jokes about employee questions regarding compensation during quarterly all hands.

-Internal hiring is a joke. Unless you personally know the manager, you're not likely to even get an email stating that they've filled the position.

-Turnover is never-ending. To go longer than a month without someone leaving the team is an anomaly.
Advice to Management
-Do a better job of making your employees feel like you care about them. It's not enough to send out an email every quarter saying "Hey everybody, we're killing it! We made so much money! Good Job!" to a bunch of people that won't see a cent of that reflected in their paycheck

-Don't make smarmy comments during all-hands meetings, it sows discontent further amongst us peons
-To tack on to the above, one of THE WORST things I've ever heard out of a VP's mouth is the phrase "We have this awesome problem of not being able to hire enough people". Think about that for a second, you have a workforce made up of extremely skilled people, each with their own network of similarly skilled individuals, but your compensation and treatment of your workers is so poor that none of us (or at least almost none of us) would ever vouch for the company. Personally, I've had several people ask me about openings within the company, and my response is "I wouldn't come here unless I was just starting out my career, re-entering the workforce after a significant gap in employment, or ready to settle down into something easy and stable a few years before retiring"

-If you're not going to institute cost of living raises, at least grant us stock options that vest over a certain amount of time. Every year we don't get a raise is technically a 2% pay cut due to inflation.

-Oh yeah, do a better job of separating SLTs politics from the company name, and stop emailing us from Lanai. Reminding us of your mind-blowing wealth is just compounding the frustration caused by the poor compensation
Be the first to find this review helpful
Helpful
Share

very low chance for a raise, even after years with the company. It is "known" that you can only get a raise with a promotion, and some people have been with the company 6+ years before getting promoted. And even then, the raise oyu are likely to get is less than you could get from a competitor.
Advice to Management
Compensate people fairly. If you truly think the knowledge and value of an employee is the same from the day they were hired after years in role, then let people know that.

review_title: They'll burn you out. You'll Only Stay for the Company Name
pros:
- You're working for a top software company so it's nice to have on your resume
- Fair salary (but you're gonna be overworked with no OT pay so not really)
- Good HMO
- They provide good work equipment
- Fun activities when in the office but that was team initiative
cons:
- Boring work. If you expect that you'll be handling Java in this company, high chances that you won't. Most likely you will be dealing with proprietary tech and worst case is even having to rely on a slow IDE on a VM to work on it. Debugging will be a headache because you won't find solutions on google. 
- It starts fine during training but once you're in the project, no work-life balance. There were many times that I did not sleep due to releases AND NO OT PAY.
- Pressure from work will burn you out.

However, I know people that wouldn't recommend because they worked in a toxic environment with terrible managers. Both can happen, both are true. Depends how lucky you are.
cons:
It's a giant company, so it's very difficult to have closer relationship and to have that family feeling with your colleagues, especially if they are spread all over the world.

cons:
lting Member of Technical Staff in Burlington, MA
Recommend
CEO Approval
Business Outlook
Pros
Depending on which department you are in you can expect interesting work, high-calibre colleagues, great flexibility, and pretty decent benefits.
Cons
There are some pretty burdensome centralized processes that make it difficult at times to get what should be straightforward tasks done efficiently. You may start off with a good salary, but once you're in, no matter how outstanding your contributions, don't expect decent raises. After almost 20 years of work there, with outstanding reviews, I just got a 1.7% raise this year -- the first one in almost five years.
Advice to Management
Don't just tell valued employees you appreciate them -- show them the money! It's disgusting that Larry Elison is worth $100B and you can't see fit to reward and retain excellent employees.

pros: It's a big company. As long as you are on the payroll you can expect to get a check every other week.
cons:
Management is constantly shifting and priorities constantly changing. If you are not well positioned as things change you will be out regardless of tenure. At least 30-40% of your working time must be oriented to politics. If you are a professional and are not a politically savvy person Oracle may not be the right place for you. Keeping your head down and doing a good job is not enough to get ahead at Oracle.

However if you are a political person, who manages up well, and can handle the work which comes with the position then Oracle is the best place for you to work.
Advice to Management
Until you can manage your people and not manage your boss your group and your tenure is doomed. Put your people first rather than putting yourself first.

review_title: Absolutely no mobility, top-down exploitative company
pros: The benefits are decent and it was reliable work from home income during the pandemic.
cons:
The role itself is designed to deal with the repercussions of technologically illiterate construction workers being forced to use an Oracle SaaS with a steep learning curve. The expectation is to keep mindlessly answering calls and thanklessly letting customers berate you with their frustrations with the service. Resources are rarely available and questions often get delayed, if any, response from peers. Management generally engages with the team with a positive attitude but gossips amongst themselves. Some managers prefer to find minutiae to penalize reps for instead of addressing larger issues that effect the entire team's workflow and morale. Promotions and raises as a whole are a facade as positions are almost always filled with outside hires. I've worked for several years and taken on several additional responsibilities than my initial job description with no increase in compensation, hoping all of it would amount to upward mobility. Even with glowing recommendations from some managers, team members, and coworkers from peripheral departments, my applications have been fruitless, usually without even a response of interest. After addressing these concerns with management, I was told to wait for more senior reps to have their chance, and to keep thanklessly picking up additional tasks and responsibilities.
Advice to Management
The CEO of this company is the 6th richest man on earth and increased his net worth by an estimated $20 billion over the course of the pandemic. He could give every single employee of this corporation a $150,000 bonus and be just as rich as he was at the beginning of the pandemic. Our department is getting work from home needlessly revoked and will be lucky to have a pizza party for our trouble when we get back in the office.

This job is thanklessly ignored by everyone above it and the corporate ladder is exponentially out of touch. Working for this company shattered a lot of my hopes for my career and keeps my mental health constantly on the floor.

review_title: I love it here, most of the time
pros: I’ve been able to move around to different teams and get a lot of diversified experience, as well as move when the situation wasn’t ideal. It’s fairly disorganized, like a teenager who still doesn’t know quite what to do but means well and has the idea. I see this as a pro because there is a ton of opportunities to shine if you’re willing to work for it.
cons:
Disorganized and lack of processes on the most critical levels - the everyday stuff. Management has a lot of churn - it’s like the weather in Seattle. If you don’t like it, just wait 5 minutes. 
One of the real cons of this is that when it comes to review time, oops, you barely know your boss. You worked hard for the last one but now they’re gone. Start over, and hope next year someone will recognize your body of work.
Advice to Management
Hire when and where it’s needed! So many dumb mistakes happen with a lack of personnel and / or knowledge. I guarantee it costs more to fix those errors (plus unfixable hits on our reputation) than to just hire enough of the right people. Having a hiring freeze on US hires for a year or so isn’t helpful.

pros: Innovative company, the best cloud platform in the market, so many resources to help you sell.
cons:
Big company feel. No real focus on employee culture. Too many leadership changes in the last three years especially in HCM applications. Get used to change at the start of every fiscal and about every 3 years highly disruptive change to employees and customers. Not a lot of rigor from leadership team or sales operations to ensure some margin of equity in account assignments. If you don’t get a good territory each fiscal year change, there’s really no appetite from leadership to add or modify account assignments despite what might be communicated. Therefore, use caution when negotiating your base salary and discussing OTE variable earnings. Sometimes it really is the luck of the draw with account assignments and many, many examples of reps not having a realistic opportunity to earn variable based on limited territory size, long sales cycles, etc.
Advice to Management
Take the time to really address the root cause of poor employee satisfaction and higher turnover especially in the field teams.

review_title: Great place to start right out of college
cons:
ltant in Austin, TX
Recommend
CEO Approval
Business Outlook
Pros
Oracle is a great company to start right out of college. It holds a lot of power in the tech world, especially if you are coming in with a non-business/tech background. You learn a lot about technology and business operations on the job.
Cons
The sales department at Oracle is very disorganized. "The only constant is change" is the tagline, but seems like an excuse because they can't get things in order. Too many overlaps within territories and too many teams aligned to certain accounts that sometimes it comes at the expense of the customer. This is especially true for the lower/entry level sales jobs outside of the field sales rep.
Advice to Management
Your success and how you feel of the company is very dependent on how well your manager guides you. Sometimes people are great sales reps but it does not make them good managers.

review_title: Oracle – The company which values a laptop more than the life of an employee during the corona virus pandemic
pros: How can Oracle have any pros when it puts an employee at a health risk during the coronavirus pandemic. Shame on you Oracle.
cons:
Firstly, let me say – The HR folks at Oracle have no control of their duties and the VP (My manager) considers himself above all company policies, compliance acts, rules, and regulations. The HR folks are mere puppets who tolerate the whims and fancies of the VP. HR keeps a blind eye as they have no control at all. The VP intervenes in tasks that do not concern his duties and HR allows the VP to do whatever the VP wants. (The VP referred here is my manager) 

Corona Virus pandemic hit us unexpectedly and my wife delivered our first baby when the virus was spreading rapidly. So, we were even more cautious and didn’t step out of the house unless and until it was an emergency ensuring the safety of our newborn child, avoided all travel, and didn’t allow anyone to enter our house in Bangalore. 

I accepted another job offer during the pandemic and I put down my papers by informing my manager who sits at a VP level as mentioned earlier. After I put down my papers, I was told by my manager to coordinate with Mr. X to do the company asset (Laptop and accessories) handover formalities on my last day. I did the same and the company asset handover was finalized with Mr. X to be done at the nearest Oracle premises near my house. I was happy that I had confirmed and finalized the asset submission at the Oracle office which was close to my residence considering the coronavirus situation that was creating havoc in Bangalore and is still creating havoc.

On my second last day at Oracle, my manager informs me that I must submit the company assets to the Oracle office which is very far from my residence, and the reason he states is that he prefers to have all assets in one place. This is even after I had confirmed the asset submission to the Oracle office that was close to my residence and even after I had requested to allow me to submit the company assets to the Oracle office close to my residence due to the corona situation in Bangalore. See the sadist behavior of my manager – He first informs me when I put down my papers to coordinate with X and do the asset handover formalities and on the second last day he intervenes and says to submit to the Oracle office that is far from my residence. The HR folks were just mere spectators, but they didn’t even bother to intervene. 

Every company across the globe is putting its best foot forward to ensure the safety of its employees as its core priority. But Oracle ensured that I am harassed and tortured mentally during the pandemic time. I wonder how such companies and managers can put someone’s life at a risk. Not only that, but my manager also wanted me to go out and exchange my laptop charger with another team member and wanted me to submit my team member's broken charger on my last working day to Oracle. I refused to exchange as I wanted to avoid meeting anyone during the pandemic and, I didn’t want to do any fraudulent activity by submitting a broken company asset back to the company. 

I was mentally harassed and tortured by this incident and I raised the harassment complaint to the top officials including the CEO. I hope the reality of the Corona Virus situation sinks into them and hopefully they realize how difficult it is to face such harassment from sadist managers and incompetent HR folks. 

The HR person who contacted me didn’t even have the courtesy to apologize for what happened and was arrogant when talking to me on such a serious sensitive issue. Instead of focusing on the harassment issue that I raised, they were interested in knowing whether I have a “PROBLEM” with my manager. See how sad their mentality is and how they are handling the harassment issue that I raised. 

I am glad that I resigned from this toxic company which put me and my family at a health risk during this corona virus pandemic. Shame on you Oracle.
Advice to Management
Learn to value a human life.

pros:
Job safety
Learning resources
Maybe work-life balance
cons:
Doesn't care about employees
Self-service mindset is the norm
No pay increase (or barely get something which is ridiculous anyways), you get more duties and responsibilities but no additional pay
Doesn't support internal job mobility nor cultural diversity, it's all about networking and nepotism/friendship
You're really on your own, you'll get help only if you end up in a good team/org
Disparate internal tools which leads to frustration and suffering
Advice to Management
Change the culture, and listen more to your staff. Cleanse the entry/mid/upper management, and get rid of those who are toxic. There's so much nepotism and favoritism happening. And surprisingly, there a lot of managers lacking common sense, compassion and respect.
Lastly, don't become AWS (gen2).

review_title: Great launching point for college grads but don't get stuck
pros: A great training program, surrounded by young college grads that you'll likely become friends with, reputable name on a resume, good pay for entry-level position especially if you're placed in a profitable org/territory.
cons:
You are just a number, sometimes feels like a boys club, account execs often make less than BDCs because deals in certain product lines (CX apps) don't close often. Marketing leads are almost never qualified.
Advice to Management
Work on retention. You spend so much on recruitment and development yet don't create an environment that talent wants to stay in. Also for the love of god fire the dead weight and use their salaries for better marketing. How else do you expect to compete with Salesforce?

pros: None that I can think of
cons:
They offer you a high OTE then they make your quota so high you can’t attain it. Then they cap you at 125%. Then, they don’t pay you the other half of your income. Then in the final quarter they make it so you get paid a minimal amount of what was owed to you from your first year’s quota but make you stay until the pay out date or they REFUSE to pay you at all. This company does not pay two week notices FYI. They do not value their employees or treat them well enough to not have a high turnover rate. 

On top of all of this, you will deal with internal oracle issues including but not limited to: CRM crashing, oracle collections harassing your customers, Internal competition, hazing from management, micromanagement, no visibility into install bases, Oracle interfering with deals to make it impossible for you to do your job correctly, demotions as soon as you sign on and honestly yet unfortunately the list goes on. 

Please beware of this company. Take notes that the culture is unbearable and they are evil. Don’t be fooled by the high OTE. Anywhere is better than Oracle by 100000000%. I wouldn’t wish this company on my worst enemy is how bad it was. Absolute torture.
Advice to Management
Fight for your employees to get paid!!! Not everyone can go without a paycheck. 
Don’t micromanage your employees. 
Give feedback!!! Grow your employees. Don’t treat them like numbers. 
Help them if they need it. 
Don’t ruin sales deals for them. 

For VP and higher: Value your employees. Make their quotas attainable. Don’t focus too much on hitting calls when the value of time with a customer is way more Important. 
Don’t let RISE calls talk down to your employees. 
Respect one another
Prorate pay checks until your compensation team can get their stuff together correctly.

review_title: It depends where you are at in your career
pros:
A good place if your new to "get started" and gain some experience
Great Colleagues
Plenty of Challenges and chances to learn
cons:
Don't expect career promotions or career advancements
Oracle Consulting is more of an experienced only consulting club, only a few entry level people will go far and that choice is not up to you
Low Pay
Poor Communication from people higher up than your direct manager
Advice to Management
Oracle Consulting is supposed to be a place where feedback should be common place and be used to better ourselves. I find it weird that when it comes to promotions, pay raises etc are left out. How am I supposed to improve myself when all my colleagues get promoted but I'm left out. I think its time to stop relying on HR and Finance in determining who gets promoted because they don't know the whole story all they get are sheets of paper. Hardly a human experience which is the antithesis of one of our 5 C's.

review_title: Great People, Leaders do not care about them
cons:
ltant 
Recommend
CEO Approval
Business Outlook
Pros
Amazing team, very talented, great team work and highly collaborative. Great work/life balance, unlimited leave, and decent health insurance.
Cons
The company does not really care about keeping or supporting employees. No regular pay raises, or bonuses regardless of personal or professional performance. They are unconcerned about attrition or lose of talent, this stems from over whelming corporate arrogance. This arrogance extends to how the executive leaders treat employees as well, be thankful that you have a job here.
Advice to Management
Oracle is making the transition to being a true cloud provider, you have many strengths and differentiators, but you are late to this game and need to make employees to know they are valued because in this market they have many more options.

1. Oracle is for people who are looking for job security. 
2. Leaves
cons:

2. Nothing new is there to explore at Oracle.
3. Salary compensation is not good compared to other big product-based MNCs.
4. Hikes/Increments are not done yearly. 
5. Oracle does not believe in retaining employees.
6. You may get a promotion but that does not entitle you to get a salary hike.
7. Every decision is made by Larry Ellison.
8. No Bonus

review_title: All in all a great workplace
pros:
- Fantastic international and young team in a great location!
- Good challenge and responsibilities working with customers and diverse product set
- Creative work, to solve customer problems
- Good culture with colleagues and management in my organization (might vary from org to org)
- Good management vision while trying to continuously reinvent the business (good and bad)
- You can grow you career in any direction, it is in your hands what you want. It is a serf service company and you will need to build your own brand within the company.
cons:
- While good compensation for the region, somewhat limited growth potential
- Constant change, somewhat insecure if strategy and roles persist over long term
Advice to Management
- Keep up good team culture, keep investing in new ideas
- While improved over the years: Keep the customer at the core of our business. 
- Do not structure your (Pre)Sales teams by product, but by industry. Bring Cloud, On-Premises, Apps and Tech together.
Be the first to find this review helpful

review_title: A Right of Passage...not a place to retire
cons:
lting Practice Manager in Atlanta, GA
Recommend
CEO Approval
Business Outlook
Pros
Exposure to leading-edge technology, top-notch resources, world-class training
Cons
Absolutely brutal workloads, typically averaging 70 hours/week for a manager. Frequent, unplanned travel which overlapped weekends. Mediocre senior management that demanded more, more, more while constantly taking away resources. Favoritism toward managers with flashy sales personalities regardless of how productive or effective they were as leaders/managers. Over-reliance on 90's-era internal systems to get work done, often requiring 50+ different logins per day.
Advice to Management
Revisit existing business processes that are document-based. Typical sales contract approval process took 3-4 weeks to finalize which often put deals at risk. Overly political management structure protected senior managers from any criticism/feedback resulting in paralysis of middle management making most employees feel like zombies just "going through the motions" because no idea/opinion went anywhere.
1 person found this review helpful
Helpful

pros: Good benefits, they won't ever fire you
cons:
Horrible company, they don't care about the employers, I had to get more than 20 calls per day while some people was getting 4 calls. The Portuguese language team have only 4 people to cover all hotels in Brazil and Portugal. They don't give you training that it will be useful for your work, they will expect you to learn the entire system in one week (Including fiscal rules for the different countries) and will put you in front of computer to get calls straight away with the same goals of the other members of the team who are working there for years. You will work on Christmas, New Years and bank holidays and do not expect any xmas bonus or pay raise. If you are not available to get calls, no matter why, more than one manager will slack you to be available every minute. Many managers from US will shame you sending emails for all the teams around the world, copying all the managers, asking you to be available in the phone even if you already got more than 20 calls and you are about to finish your shift. Do not expect to have a career opportunity, because it doesn't happen for employers who start working on L1 of support.
Advice to Management
I don't recommend you to get this job.

ltant in Austin, TX
Recommend
CEO Approval
Business Outlook
Pros
Salary was fine, but there were none of the perks you find at other big tech companies like Facebook or Google--no free snacks, have to pay for the gym onsite, etc. 
You don't have to work very hard as a BDC/sales development representative/whatever they're calling the role nowadays. But you are VERY dependent on your sales rep to "help" you find opportunities.
Cons
I wish people had warned me about the fratty culture. Oracle sales purportedly hires "leaders", which includes former college athletes, student council members, etc. and ultimately results in a lot of former fraternity/sorority members being hired. The environment is quite literally collegiate, in that all the bonding activities involve drinking and people act like they're still living out their frat-bro days. It doesn't help that they hire in such large batches (I started with 100 people in the Austin office) and with so many people fresh out of college, which leads to the same cliquey-ness and gossip that freshman year of college entailed.
Advice to Management
Stop promoting people who are "good at sales" into management positions. Being a good salesperson does not mean you'll be good at management. In fact, it often means the opposite. You can't hound your subordinates into doing better, the way you can hound a customer into buying something or at least taking your call.
5 people found this review helpful

Give incentives to people staying in company.

review_title: Good culture, hard to make the big bucks
pros: The overall culture is very good
cons:
Small sales territories, difficult to hit a big #, most reps don't get to 50% of annual quotas.
Advice to Management
Good culture and a good company overall. 

It's clear they've gone the way of increasing the top line at all costs, with no consideration to territory size, % of AEs that hit quota, etc..

The team I was on had 8 AEs. 1/8 hit their annual quota. Average quota attainment was >33%. 

Long story short, it's very difficult to hit a big # based on demand and territory sized. They've hired too many people in Sales.

pros: Stable company, interesting products and technologies. They hire very talented developers and motivated sales people. Great for those who are ambitious.
cons:
American based, where they easily forget satellite and remote workers even exist. Large org where managers look to build empires, focusing decisions and solutions on short term gains, and credit is taken for others work. Don't help others in such an organization as there is nothing in it for you, and nothing lasts very long, even good will.
Advice to Management
Lip service is paid to noble goals and initiatives, but they are a farce that doesn't go down even one level of very significant management hierarchies. Management focuses on a few who progress while the rest are left leaving for advancement or resenting the lack of communication and inclusion in decision processes.

review_title: Low pay and began to Micro manage as well feeling like a Call Center.
pros: Great benefits and a good job for those who are fresh out of college. Oracle is a great company if you are lucky to be chosen by another department. This job is not so time consuming unless you don't know how to be organize.
cons:
Low pay, management is not fair and at least in this department in San Antonio, you will never get a raise or be able to move up. Been in the company for many years now as well as 50 plus of us and only 3 people have gotten a raise and the other 30 have quit. But they will give you more work for sure!
Advice to Management
Focus on the ones who have given you their time and years instead of giving Management raises. That is how the whole department will want to work harder instead of having to lose 2 employees per month.

review_title: It could be a really good company to work for. Unless you end up in a toxic environment
pros: Good networking; if you are good, other well established companies will try to head hunt you; possibility to change team/Lob; solid company; they have an office in Malaga, a paradise in terms of quality of life; good products (PaaS and IaaS are becoming to get noticed)
cons:
It seems that senior leaders at Oracle are closing both eyes on bad sales practices. Also, despite all their claims of being against gender discrimination, and wanting to support women, I witnessed several woman that after becoming mum, the senior manager took away the good customers/territories from her, and she does not receive any "congratulations" message from the company either (if she is lucky, her manager and co-workers will send it to her).
Targets are really high and far from being achievable (I guess this is the way they keep costs down). Career promotion is unclear (I once saw the partner of a manager being promoted, while other sales reps with better performance were not).
Not saying every manager/director is toxic. Not at all! I had the luxury to meet both types during my several years at Oracle Digital in Malaga. Good luck.

review_title: Great school, everything else is horrible
pros: young and great colleagues, good on your CV, good work life balance
cons:
- it's a very hostile environment and everyone works kind of against everyone
- therefore people usually have a bad work attitude and you have to be scared that someone else "steals" your deal because they believe it's their account, not yours
- two years ago Oracle decided they now have to be customer centric (after >40 years they finally realized that...), as of now, they are not at all; they keep making the customers' lives hard, even just changing an e-mail address for the customer has to be done by the customer himself and can't be handled internally
- management is a disaster, no people management at all, they don't know how the real business is running, especially VP who has zero contact to the account managers, who do the actual work; no support during corona at all, no equipment, no appearance in team meetings by VP, no understanding, just being told to put books under our laptops...
- no onboarding, all self service only; new hires rely fully on helpful colleagues
- no people management, no development opportunities, no matter how hard you work
- new hires want to leave as soon as possible, waiting for their relocation budget to expire (bound for 1,5 years)
- it depends fully on your customer patch on how much money you make
- customers hate Oracle, no one is happy when you call and they usually had bad experiences with Oracle
- nothing is easy, every process is difficult, even just changing a customer's address
- men get paid more and have higher IC levels
- many people are leaving because there is no opportunities, no support during corona and the only fun thing (going to the office, colleagues) is not really present anymore
- no values
Advice to Management
TALK to your sales reps and don't decide on things without knowing how things actually run, be more approachable, be empathetic, give them opportunities and motivate them!!!!

review_title: School for IT SaaS Sales. But you get fed up at your 3 year mark.
pros:
You learn a lot, it is a great school for rising IT and SaaS Salespeople.
The commission pay looks good on paper, but be careful. You will only receive more than half of that commission if you had a good territory where the is not much internal competition.
cons:
Base salary and benefits are not as good as the rest of the key players in the industry and region.

No career progression. Only way to get promoted is to move to one of the competitors and then move back. Even annual wage increase is not being done.

Very competitive and hostile environment to work in. Everyone is always angry or annoyed, pressured by their management.

Internal systems feel like you are working for a poor third-world country's government from how bureaucratic the company is.
Advice to Management
Resign and give room for younger, more fit people to lead. Your school of management is clearly not working, or otherwise you would not have such a high employee turnover.

review_title: Salary hike dont match with company growth
pros: Good technology company as you are working in product company. Get to work in new technologies and good profile.
cons:
Company has a strange policy, where company don't consider giving salary hike. Appraisal process is never in sync with package increment, both run independently. Local management looks to be helpless and don't have any hold on salary hike. Oracle follows a strange appraisal system where employee needs to get some offer from other company to proves his own worth, even though you perform well and has been appreciated by manager or appraisal system. Employee work for 3 to 4 years without hike but any new joinee filling the same position will be paid huge salary hike compared to his current package. Work life balance all depends upon the Team and manager.
Advice to Management
Try to share some business profit with company root level employee too, who are the part of your company journey and are equally responsible for the company growth .

review_title: Toxic environment - execs do not care about employees
pros: Benefits seemed good. Access to training on Oracle technologies.
cons:
Oracle tech is not the leading edge and you will lose marketable skills working there. Even in management, there is no career development that will transfer to another company. Raises are few and far between and never touch everyone - high salaries, raises and options/rsu's are reserved for the elite in OCI. Certain high level execs manage through fear and tantrums and have no clue how to run a customer focused enterprise software/cloud services company. OCI managers will often call other teams in Oracle stupid and useless and old and that attitude pervades the organization and is reinforced by the OCI HR - which is a distinct org from regular Oracle HR.
Advice to Management
Get this OCI/Oracle division straightened out and start working like a cohesive company. OCI people are not better than other Oracle employees. Stop treating the company like your own dividend cash machine and start investing in employees and technology. Employees live in fear because that is the environment created by Larry from the top down.
