ltant in Santa Monica, CA
Recommend
CEO Approval
Business Outlook
Pros
The people you work with are smart, driven recent grads. Great opportunity to network and make friends with good people. Direct managers are supportive and want you to do well. Oracle is also a good name to have on your resume to find a higher paying job.
Cons
Unfortunately, the way BDCs are treated is not the best. Middle management micromanages and makes every aspect of the job way more difficult than necessary. Pay is lower than what many competitors pay. KPIs are entirely arbitrary to the point where people just make stuff up to rank higher despite not bringing in any value.
Advice to Management
Stop treating people like numbers and show some trust

review_title: Not the Best, Not The Worst
cons:
ltant 
Recommend
CEO Approval
Business Outlook
Pros
It’s a large company so it has a pretty predictable structure, benefits, and requirements. Opportunity to move internally if needed is available. Supportive managers
Cons
Few/no raises, arbitrary promotion criteria that changes constantly, high and low performers are equally valued. High turnover.
Advice to Management
Incentives could be more aligned to encourage teams to provide high value to our customers. Right now the reward for doing great work is being loaded up with more work, which is why retention is so low.

review_title: Valuable experience overall where you learn and grow through painful experiences.
pros:
High end in job training
Variable compensation IF you get a good patch
cons:
No recognition for achievements, SVP that encourage you to do malpractice activities, threatens you on sundays.
No vision, no mission, the only value and only objective is short term money, regardless of clients needs and common long term business.

Also, for a so called technologie leaders, you should see the stupid processes that we have to go through to get anything done. You spend more time talking to different layers of management and deal with some very user friendly systems than building relationship and selling value & experience to your customer/prospect.

Although lots of very competent IC’s, management is a mix of very good/experienced and terrible toxic counter productive short term personal career oriented “leader”.

Pay attention to your initial négociation, because once accepted you package is likely to evolve very slowly.

Not only you’ll have to perform (obvious) but you’ll also have to deal with complex situation were management is asking you to work for “free” or encourage you to do malpractice activities.
Advice to Management
None, as they couldn’t care less!

pros: This is not a tough job, but it does not pay well. There is low stress mainly because your territory's success is largely out of your control, and has more to do with history of oracle in that territory than your own efforts. That said it is getting much easier to bring in greenfield customers through OCI
cons:
Oracle changes quotas and territories so frequently that it is very tough to establish real customer relationships, and build business within one account. It's much more of a luck of the draw scenario, than an opportunity to build a business as an AW
Advice to Management
Keep reps in the same territory each year, and offer promotions into better territories for senior reps, instead of readjusting territories each year and throwing new reps into the best territories.

pros: I joined Oracle as part of an acquisition and really never expected to enjoy such a huge company, but I'm finding it a great place to work. The work is rewarding and challenging, and the culture is super supportive. It's a great place for women and I see a good gender balance across my org. Work/life balance is excellent, benefits are superb and there is a fantastic level of care provided to employees.
cons:
Some processes can be heavy-handed and this can slow progress. Pay scales are excellent, but once on a pay grade, rises are fairly rare. Promotions are more likely to come via re-orgs. Gender balance is good, but more work could be put into diversity in other areas.
Advice to Management
Support employees in their upward career paths. As frustrating as it might be to lose good staff to higher salary offers, sometimes it's the only way to keep people.

review_title: BDC at Oracle GBU in Dublin
cons:
ltant in Dublin, Dublin
Recommend
CEO Approval
Business Outlook
Pros
- Great workplace to kickoff your career in sales
- Benefits (insurance, extra holidays to purchase, etc.) are great
- Flexibility and lack of constant pressure or micro management
Cons
- Low wages compared to most SDR/BDR tech companies 
- Non defined progression paths 
- Comission calculator doesn't exist: what you get on a quarterly basis can't be calculated in a transparent way. Overachievers sometimes get less bonus than promised
Advice to Management
- Some managers have no previous experience in real sales (account management, new business executives, etc.) which leads to unrealistic advice and coaching. I would advise them to get more sales training that can really help their reps

- Be more upfront and transparent regarding promotions

review_title: Solid Company - Good Worklife Balance, Great Insurance Benefits but Tough to Get Promoted or Salary Increases
pros:
These are for Oracle Data Cloud business arm - (Adtech-Martech)

* Collaborative and fun work culture
* Excellent Insurance Benefits
* Excellent Parental Leave - (up to 10 weeks for both parents)
* Flexible Work Schedules - (If you are delivering innovation and value)
* Colleagues in general are smart and helpful
* Great amenities such as gyms, cafeterias , outdoor workspaces
* Vacation is not necessarily tracked.
* Very relaxed work attire requirements unless meeting with clients
cons:
* Very difficult to get raises or promotions so ensure you ask for compensation and title that you expect to have for many years to come when being hired. After seven years of working for ODC, there still does not seem to be an annual review process so even getting standard cost of living raises are difficult.

* Lots of bureaucracy within the product, engineering, and legal teams so very slow or difficult to consistently release products and/or product features. Very difficult to be innovative and keep up with industry competition

* Product leadership and vision seem to change very often. This can impact current projects being worked on and therefore, lot of "throw-a-away" work can be expected

* Currently, only one overarching design team so not all product teams have access to working with designers to create innovative and industry leading digital products. Sometimes, product leads have to wear many hats.

* Product leads often have to wear many hats such as designer, UX researcher, market researcher, Product Marketer, Technical Product Manager vs Product Owner, scrum master, project manager, product tester and system troubleshooter / tester. This can lead to some long nights and also impact speed of product releases

* Engineering resources always seem to be limited and not enough for building all the products and platforms leadership wants to build so again, progress can be slow
Advice to Management
* Build a strong and cohesive product organization that puts innovation and speed to market first and foremost. 

* Decrease dependencies on so many teams to release products or features.

* Compensate people aligned to industry averages. 

* Have yearly review processes if, for nothing else, to provide performance feedback if not assess availability for salary increase and/or promotions

pros: Downtime at beginning of quarter months
cons:
Compensation is broken. Company regularly increases base salary for external applicants but freezes salary for internal employees. Internal transfers are compensated based on their initial salary instead of the new role’s salary range. It’s not uncommon for internal employees to leave Oracle for 12 months and then return as an “external applicant” just to level the playing field. All the top performers leave once they find this out and the bottom of the barrel performers remain. 

Extreme overtime and working conditions (ex: working until 12, 1, 2am and then returning to regular working hours the next morning)
Advice to Management
Wake up and fix the broken comp system at the source, you’re hemorrhaging external salary increases and on boarding costs while losing anyone of actual value.

review_title: Oracle is an accounting-focused company, not a sales focused comany
pros:
Lots of spots to hide out and collect a base. If your idea of "sales" is "Audit Bargain Close" (google it) and you enjoy parsing through contracts to move the customer spend from one bucket to another, then this is the place for you.

Upward mobility because of high turnover.

You'll also get a big pay bump when you leave.
cons:
Go-to-market is terrible. Over half of reps won't even get to 10% of their number. 90% won't even get to 75% of their number. The outliers who hit their number generally do so when an existing customer naturally expands and the "Audit Bargain Close" process "works". This low attainment is despite the org itself hitting it's number most quarters. Which, mathematically, means that quotas are over-assigned by 4-6x most years. The solution year after year isn't that Oracle's GTM needs to change, it's that they must have hundreds of bad sales reps, thus the high "warm body" churn rates. 

Further disincentives to collaborate, if there is a co-prime, you are cut off at a certain threshold. In other words, you don't want to work a deal "too big" or it will get taken away. This leads to poor communication and confusion of the prospect/customer. 

Churn and burn culture with a warm body in place. Oracle treats sales as a cost, not an investment. No incentive to cross sell or collaborate with your co-workers. This leads to a high loss rate to competitors who sell strategically. It also leads to a dishonest work environment in terms of deal collaboration. Close rate is around 10% mind you. 

Oracle rewards Audit Bargain Close and moving a customers spend from one bucket to another and neglects any kind of incentive to find genuine new revenue.

Vast majority of sales managers and even VPs have never sold genuine net new revenue, but got to where they are by the same Audit Bargain Close methodology, reading Oracle contracts to exploit the comp plan, or have managed KPI-based sales "support orgs" and somehow moved into managing sales. Thus, they have no real ideas of how to find new revenue. Oracle's revenue hasn't grown in 8 years, so obviously no one is actually selling genuine net new revenue. High customer churn because Oracle would rather pay audit jockeys to screw over customers than hire enough customer success managers.



TL;DR, is this the kind of company you want to "sell" for?

Oracle's revenue hasn't grown in 8 years, yet EPS has. High churn and low sales payouts (due to most reps not even remotely getting to their targets despite the org number as a whole being 100%+).

Oracle has been sued multiple times for "Audit Bargain Close" sales tactics. This leads to high customer churn because Oracle doesn't understand that modern technology isn't as monolithic or hard to remove as it was in the 90s. 

There is an entire industry dedicated to servicing Oracle customers and protecting them from over usage and being audited.

This is not a sales company, it is a legal/accounting company. It's a shame because the technology itself is world class.
Advice to Management
Treat sales as a revenue center, not a cost center.

Cut the bloated sales ops staff by 60% or pay them based on rep retention/% of reps participating.

Comp people based on genuine net new revenue, not calling a customer and saying "you're over your usage, pay us" or convincing a customer to simply re-sign an ordering document under a new SKU name so the rep gets paid without creating any value.

Fire yourself if you got into your position of upper management but haven't carried a bag in 20 years.

review_title: Avoid Oracle BDC Org At All Costs
pros: Having the name on your resume while applying to other jobs... Although that does not seem to carry much weight anymore.
cons:
Not sure if Oracle has bots leaving fake reviews here to cover up the truth about working in the BDC org, but here is the truth: it is the most exploitative sales program out there. They randomly place BDCs into different lines of business, which end up having different pay structures. You will find yourself making more or less than someone who applied to the same role (regardless of performance). They will promise you $25k of performance-based compensation and tell you that you will get it if you hit your number during recruiting. You will end up attaining over 200% of your quota and not make full bonus. They will tell you that you can promote quickly. You will soon find out that "promotion" means getting a slightly (and I mean slightly) higher base and new title to do the same job after a year of being a BDC - if you are lucky. The road to the top at Oracle is endless.

Outside of the external competitors (who have far superior products than Oracle) you will also find yourself calling against many other teams within Oracle. This creates many confused and angry clients when you do get them on the phone or email. The training organization neglects giving you a complete understanding of the products you sell, but instead focuses on teaching you how to be manipulative and lie on the phone. The KPI structure for making bonus is nothing but subjective busy work. An "opp" does not come down to what you discover at an account, but how lenient your assigned Account Manager is.

In summary, you have no control over your destiny here. I am familiar with the common pitfalls of Corporate America. At Oracle, it is different. Leaving this company was the best decision I could have made. Hopefully this review will help someone make an even better decision of not working here at all.

review_title: Attrition has been high due to recent events and no pay raise
pros:
Great people if you find the right organization to work with
Oracle is a good stepping stone if you're out of college
Health Benefits are great
cons:
Oracle decided to move HQ to Austin, TX which became effective late 2020. It was planned a long time ago so nothing to be angry there. Oracle is backfilling any departures in Austin, TX where possible. TX is employer friendly compared to CA. 

My review is from a non-OCI / non-engineering role -- this might not be applicable to you. Oracle is known for no pay raises. You can google it and it would be the top result. The average length of employees is around 2-3 years because they realized.. wow it is true. Time to find a better paying job. I have seen ex-coworkers get 40% raises by accepting outside jobs. I did the same. 

What's maddening is when I discussed pay with a peer.. I discovered that as a new hire.. I was paid more than him and he had been there 4 years already. Oracle doesn't value talent or loyalty. 

I have seen people request a match to stay but HR would say no. Your management chain will have no power. However, they would hire a total newbie for the pay that the person requested.. Oracle cannot retain talent. On blind -- I have seen someone polled offers between google and Oracle. all the Oracle employees said choose google.. you can chill and get pay raises. lolll it's funny how all oracle employees were on the same page. doesn't look good externally. 

Advice for anyone that wants a raise at Oracle -- apply to another position internally. That's the only way.
Advice to Management
Executive management must evaluate the culture of the company towards their employees. I have seen and heard various organizations lose 15-30% headcount since January 2021 with more in the process of leaving. It would be silly to assume that C-suite haven't realized that they're bleeding more people than usual. Top performers are leaving and it's a pain to ramp new hires in 6 months when fiscal year is about to end. I doubt anyone cares but it's cheaper to keep top performers that can do the task of two ICs than have a churn of employees every 2 years. You lose alot of money in tribal knowledge and hiring. 

When I accepted an outside offer -- at least 4 others asked for help so they can update and job hunt themselves. The floodgates are open and companies are willing to pay 30% for all the employees that you have trained. Oracle needs to pay more and retain their talent to win the cloud war. The ball is in your court.
Be the first to find this review helpful
Helpful

review_title: Unless you're desperate for a job, stay away.
pros:
Initially, I thought pay. They managed to screw that up. 
401k & health Benefits were very good.
cons:
In my experience this was the most Dysfunctional company I've ever worked for. Constant internal fighting for deals and stealing of deals. Other internal teams actively blocking you in accounts. Can't get commission checks right, and forget about base pay raises. Most customers hated Oracle. Typically because they felt they were cheated or abused by Oracle at some point. In my experience, their anger was usually justified. People/recruiters often commented they were surprised how long I'd stayed at Oracle as they have such a bad reputation in the industry. I recommend you look elsewhere for employment, and only consider Oracle as a last resort.
Advice to Management
After multiple years of employee surveys being ignored, I don't think anything I say would matter.

pros:
1. A lot of opportunities to learn
TIP: Go and ask for new work that come. No one is going to know that you are capable unless you tell them.
2. Very Chill People in the team
3. Apply for internal switching to different project and it gives you completely new environment and growth opportunities
4. Good Pay initially (but salary is not increased very often)
cons:
1. Personal Growth and learning can be hindered by your manager as they will expect you to work on only the things they assign and sometimes it doesn't align with your growth
2. HR don't take actions unless higher management gets involved.
3. You have to buy food. No free food available 😭
Advice to Management
See that lower level managers are not creating too much pressure on the developers.
( All I asked was for 1 day leave so that my eye condition gets better. I couldn't even see the screen without getting water from my eyes and they were completely red and was hurting really badly. 
My manager wrote me a very diplomatic e-mail to tell me not to think of taking a leave again as it was impacting her work. My medical condition got worse because of her behaviour and pressure to keep working and eventually I resigned as I will not work for a company who doesn't respect their employees and care about their health.)

review_title: A Company That Apprecitiates Wall Street More Than Employees
pros: Learning channels and opportunities - lots of; Global company that allows you to work intensively with people all over the world; Lots of opportunities to make significant contributions; Company culture really depends on your boss - can be real good or can be real bad
cons:
Very difficult to move across functions; Be prepared to not receive any salary raise or promotion in many many many years -- regardless of your performance or contributions; If you have a bad boss then your life could be horrible.
Advice to Management
Sr. management team should have regular one-one skip level interviews with staff down the structure, and should take their input into serious decision making; A company exists not just for sales and business, but for its people first -- remember one thing: happy employee happy customers.

review_title: Good first job that can lead to better things if you look outside of the company.
cons:
ltant in Austin, TX
Recommend
CEO Approval
Business Outlook
Pros
-Great opportunity for someone fresh out of college with little experience
-You're starting with a class of 100s of other people around your age, easy to make friends
-Pretty easy to be successful. Most of the class is frat bros/sorority girls who are really there more to socialize and have fun than they are to work. Nothing wrong with that, but if your goal is to be good at your job and make a lot of money you can rank at the top every quarter if you're willing to put in just a little effort. 
-Honestly really good pay for what is essentially a glorified telemarketing job.
Cons
-Job is not fulfilling at all
-Micromanagement
-Lack of transparency, KPIs that don't make sense
-Constant changes, your job is more about fake metrics (# of calls per day, quick tours) than it is actual sales (creating legitimate opportunities)
-Lack of promotion opportunities. A lot of the promotions to move up from BDC look like promotions in title, but actually end up paying less
-Training is lackluster. I personally don't feel like I developed many real skills after my first month or two.
-Experience will be mostly dependent on what team you end up on. It's completely random. Some products are way easier to sell. Some managers are super chill and others will micromanage you to the death and make you want to find another job immediately.

pros:
I worked at Oracle for 3.5+ years. Started in the Class Of program when it included a trip to California. The company did a great job of introducing everyone to tech sales. Pre-Covid, Class Of was a good way to make friends and score some freebies. 

The people are one of Oracle's best assets. It's easy to network and make friends since most people are willing to help and don't act too pretentious.

You get to choose from a number of locations across the country. However, salaries are fixed so your dollar will probably go farther in Austin than in Santa Monica.

Bonuses/Commission rates used to be better and promotions used to be plentiful. It was fairly common for a BDC to get promoted to a closing role after 1+ year in seat. Wasn't unheard of for recent college graduates to be making close to 6 figures.

Benefits are pretty solid, nothing to complain about here.

Sales training is top-notch. However, only recently did the company start caring about giving its salespeople a strong technical foundation.

Overall, a lot of Oracle's pros can be found at any other large tech company.
cons:
Oracle is a behemoth of a company. You're just a number and any recognition you'll receive for doing a good job will be shortly met with a "what have you done for me lately?" mentality from your boss/director. 

Decision-making is a privilege reserved solely for upper management who rarely if ever step foot on the sales floor. For example, FY20 brought sweeping changes to OD Sales, with tons of people demoted without notice. I had 6 different managers my final year at the company. Sales here is a total revolving door.

Promotions are much harder to come by now as Covid led to several hiring freezes. The company would rather hire more Class Ofs for less money than promote internally or hire from the outside. Speaking of which, every account has upwards of 50 sales reps all calling into the same DBA, IT Manager, etc. so that by the time you reach out, you'll most likely be hung up on or sent straight to voicemail.

With promotions come minuscule 5% salary increases and unreasonable sales targets and commission rates.

BDCs, Inside Sales, and Field Sales, are often pitted against each other due to asinine territory management plans. Instead of working together to sell across product verticals, sales reps have to horde opporunity intelligence to ensure they can hit their quotas.

While Oracle does well in HW, On premise DB, and some SaaS, its PaaS & IaaS offerings are sorely lacking and the pressure to compete with the likes of AWS and Azure falls, unfortunately, on the sales reps.

While Oracle may be a well-known name to add to a resume, I'd highly suggest looking elsewhere. Or, at the very least, not spending too much time here.
Advice to Management
Stick to what you do well. Trying to compete with AWS and Azure places way too much stress on your salespeople.

review_title: Lots of opportunity in NetSuite Customer Success
cons:
lting Manager 
Recommend
CEO Approval
Business Outlook
Pros
I have been a part of NetSuite’s Customer Success practice for the past 8 years. What I have consistently seen is considerable growth opportunities for those who perform and seek them out. NS has been growing consistently for my entire tenure, and that growth has accelerated since Oracle’s acquisition. Despite being part of Oracle, NS still operates as a separate GBU and has maintained it’s culture. NS is still small enough to be able to make a difference and stand out. There are significant advancement opportunities for those who perform. Don’t believe the myths about NS moving all of its onshore consulting roles to Manila and India. NS is growing both onshore and offshore aggressively and the two teams work as one global team.

If you’re ambitious and looking to grow your career while getting exposure to a world-class Cloud-based Customer Success operation, I would recommend joining NS. 

Note - NS delivers a large portion of manager comp through annual RSU grants and quarterly variable payouts, so be wary of the base salary data. Likewise, NS provides individual contributors with consistent quarterly discretionary variable payouts which makeup a large percent of total comp.
Cons
None - It has all the ingredients you need....it is what you make of it.

pros: Flexible in that you can work from home, "unlimited vacation" if your manager let's you take it, and decent benefits.
cons:
There are a lot of cons, but the primary offense is the systemic misogyny and racism that constantly are identified and ignored. Women are paid far less and tasked with far more. Men are given promotions for doing much less. They refuse to actually do a salary comparison because they know the results will be bad and could implicate them in various lawsuits that are ongoing. A few final notes: bad actors are not punished but rather promoted, pay increases almost never occur, management is tone deaf, and the reward for good work is a lot more work.
Advice to Management
Get most of management out, they refuse to see/change the systemic issues.

review_title: Weird culture, no experience recognition - qunatity over quality.
pros: If you have the strength to do your job, compensating for the lack of tech know how of the lower manager tier -while learning other stuff, is a great place to learn new things - due to Oracle University ( free online classes, books, knowledge database for hundreds of topics related or not directly to tech).
cons:
No recognition for the extra tasks.
No time allocation for extra task ( you have to do within the same 8 hours what you used to do + a lot more free of extra payment).
Some lower tier managers have the audacity to demand over-time.
Most middle tier/ upper tier managers don't care about Customer satisfaction, the only goal is to close as many tickets as possible.
Low to no knowledge from most of Fusion Cloud Implementation Consultants - majority log tickets seeking solutions not usage/ testing responses on various issues encountered.
2/3 of all Support Engineers don't have prior understanding of business flows and refuse learning it.
2/3 of all Support Engineers wanna pass their job to those 1/3 that care for Customer or wanna learn stuff.
Advice to Management
Stop asking contradicting stuff through the procedures you deploy for Oracle Fusion Support - and try to stop tolerating brain dead attitude from those having it - among employees.

ltant in Santa Monica, CA
Recommend
CEO Approval
Business Outlook
Pros
If you work hard and show initiative (networking, positive attitude, etc.), there’s no reason why you won’t get promoted into a closing role. Benefits and compensation are decent too. I’ve never been micromanaged and have had positive experiences with all my managers.
Cons
Certainly, customer perception and (probably) the products themselves aren’t up to the competition’s standards. This isn’t really an issue for BDCs and their short-term success in the role, but it makes long-term trajectory (from a resume, career-building, and compensation perspective) a little more hazy than ideal.
Advice to Management
I think the BDCs are really well managed at Oracle — not sure any of the listed qualms are particularly actionable for them.

review_title: Netsuite Oracle - Great if you have a good manager. If not, good luck lmao....
cons:
ltant in Mississauga, ON
Recommend
CEO Approval
Business Outlook
Pros
- Lucked out with an AMAZING manager and great team
- Current manager provided interesting work and targets were always attainable without much overtime
Cons
- The gentleman who onboarded me and my group was absolutely awful, not knowledgable and made a lot of the fellow graduates I onboarded with uncomfortable. We gave feedback to this once our onboarding process was completed and NO RESPONSE FROM HR. DISAPPOINTED!!!! 
-Your experience is 100% based on who your manager is and if they advocate for you and care about your growth OR if they just care about themselves. I literally saw colleagues under a different manager in a different team get thrown under the bus by their managers. Not cool. 
- Promotion structure so rigid and not easy to switch departments
Advice to Management
- Only be a manager if you actually care about people, not to fulfill your ego. 
- SCREEN who you hire to have as your onboarding team PROPERLY. This is the first contact new hires have with your company and your brand.
Be the first to find this review helpful

review_title: Oracle is a nice place to work, Brand
pros: Oracle brand, Working culture, learning curve, ownership
cons:
Management is Bias, No promotion, No hike, No growth
Advice to Management
“Treat people how you like to be treated”. If any employees approached his/her manager for any concern, listen, and solve the issue rather playing a game and creating issues within the colleagues. And don’t treat them bad/speak rude during the team meetings, appraisal discussion rude, nor act like one teen kid, but be matured enough to handle the situation. Promotions should be based on the appraisal rating & the work done by an individual not based on who is close to the manager, it always mismatches. The ratings are always 4 & 5, but no promotion.
Don’t give false promises that there will be no layoff, but actual layoff happened and that too with an excellent performers & not the poor performer.

der
3 Mar 2021 - Sales Manager 
Recommend
CEO Approval
Business Outlook
Pros
If you’re in the first few years of your career, you can learn a lot. If you’re more than 4-5 years into your career, there’d be no reason to work for NetSuite. The office cultures have good energy, but with Covid, things have of course changed and many of the folks who were based in offices have moved back to where they are from.
Cons
Micro-Management across the board. 
Compensation not market-competitive. 
Overly-political, where promotions are given out to people who’ve been there a long time, not on merit. 
NetSuite having great difficulty selling to upmarket and are focusing efforts on small (1-5M revenue) companies - will not learn enterprise, strategic selling. 
Reps and Managers, alike, succeed by being CRM aces rather than Sales aces. Very little true development- it’s all about how well you can manipulate your CRM.
Advice to Management
The train has left the station.

review_title: Great colleagues, but little opportunity for advancement
pros: My colleagues and immediate management were generally excellent; I learned a lot during my time at Oracle, and there are frequently new challenges, or new things to learn. The benefits were great. I enjoyed flexible hours.
cons:
No bonuses and raises were few and far between; generally, the pay was below standard. Also, it wasn't possible to advance beyond a front line manager position (unless I had decided to move to San Antonio, perhaps).
Advice to Management
Pay a little more to keep your best talent (I'm not even talking about myself; the teams I worked on bled an incredible amount of talent because the company wouldn't pay its best employees more). I don't expect this to change.

- growing fast, still at an early stage, and working on ambitious new initiatives.
- Engineers at any level can have significant technical and business impact
- flexi work culture, able to balance work/life
- great support infra for female employees (creche, etc)
- new campus with great facilities :-)
cons:
- initial transition is difficult if you come from old work culture of only focusing on development. in the new world where your offering as-a-service, one must own design/dev/test/ops, end-to-end.

More focus on Diversity and Inclusion

cons:
Everything is about process, not in the way of trying to make things more efficient but red tape for administrative justification. You will be exhausted by having 2 jobs, your actual day job and the job of navigating internal politics.

Remove the middle management layer and have people actually doing their jobs, not just for show.

pros: Learned a lot at the company, they offer the opportunity for a lot of resources for your development if you seek it out.
cons:

Helpful
Share
Repor

pros:
- Career Development opportunities
- Lots of sales training is offered 
- You work with very well experienced colleagues who you can learn a lot from 
- The company is focusing more on Diversity & Inclusion as well as on Volunteering opportunities (though I haven't seen an increase in D&I colleagues yet?)
- The commission. Oracle has very fruitful commission schemes that I haven't seen at other Corporate companies. Hence, if you are very driven to close and want to make a lot of money, Oracle is definitely the place to be in Sales
- Good benefit scheme (private insurance, dental insurance, health and wealth schemes)
- Working from home
cons:
- Not much space for creativity & corporate messaging is encouraged when reaching out to prospects
- Internal processes are a nightmare (although you can get support here when you know the right people) 
- Very corporate company. There is absolutely no focus on building team spirit, have fun/engaging activities across the Group. Everyone is just working for themselves and that's all
- No Culture and Values (internally speaking)
- Internal transfers: you do not get paid fairly when progressing internally vs. external candidates who come in
Advice to Management
1/ Give sales the space to develop relevant value propositions for customers instead of sending Oracle focused/corporate content 2/ Award internal promotion. So far employees who progress in Oracle, are disadvantaged financially speaking. External candidates get a much higher salary and a higher level than internal candidates. Internal progression can take very slow too, which is why people leave the company for a much better salary (at least 150% higher). 3/ Bring back the sales spirit. After covid, organise team building events, award high performers with not just recognition but also awards or a small gesture. 4/ Hire more D&I employees

pros: Decent benefits, opportunities for bonuses
cons:
There is a culture of cheating on certification examinations; employees are tacitly encouraged to seek out test dumps before taking cert tests. Upper management only wants to see certification percentage increase, regardless of the actual skill of the employees. Certifications that are supposed to require 2 years of experience before completion are expected to be obtained in 6 months or less, and it still affects bonuses.
Very political atmosphere between organizations within the company, almost like competing against different companies.
Advice to Management
Focus on fostering technical skills rather than the appearance of technical skill, and change the incentive structure to reduce infighting.

pros:
-Great place to learn the ropes of Saas and/or tech sales.
-Some people make a lot of money
-Few people are laid off
cons:
-Turnover is so high I only know of small HR companies like ADP with similar attrition 
-Terrible pay increases. Colleagues, and myself included, would be paid anywhere from $30k-$50k less than "professional hires" with no software sales experience doing the exact same job. Promotion from within is rare and comes with a fractional increase in pay. (Example: Going for a field role after being at the company for 5 years you would be offered $80k while outside hires would be offered $110k+).
-Account Executives are paid $7k more than Business Development 
-Oracle is big enough that it doesn't feel the need to pay it's sales force well and it's felt across the sales culture
Advice to Management
Lower attrition and increase culture by paying your sales force the market value of the enterprise software/technology industry and encourage internal promotions (with consistent amounts) rather than hiring externally (and offering more).

Helpful

review_title: Lots of perks and opportunities for internal mobility
pros:
- Very competitive compensation package including stock options
- Amazing benefits that you would expect at a huge company
- A culture around learning and development with great resources like LinkedIn Learning, access to Harvard Business Review, hundreds of curated learning paths, etc.
- Recent push to encourage employees to pursue opportunities outside their department but within the company, while providing the leadership guidance and technical tools to make this easy
- Remote-friendly
cons:
- I've had colleagues who've lost their job every year since I've been here (terminations and reductions in force or RIFs)
- Things move pretty slowly
- Lots and lots of processes
Advice to Management
Thanks for the great resources to continue to learn and develop.

review_title: Not as bad a place as people think of it to be
pros:
- Good Salary
- Good Health Insurance
- The Oracle Cloud team has some amazingly smart and hardworking people
cons:
- The sales/account/support teams are living in the 00’s with the classical enterprise software mentality. Oracle is now a cloud company but the other teams are not in sync and still operate in their lazy condescending attitude 
- The sales people have tarnished the company’s image with many customers. 
- The company is like a giant oil tanker and it is being made to do a u-turn and it will take sometime before the company culture is changed
Advice to Management
- Adopt the work culture of the other Hyperscalers
- Identify key resources and compensate and grow them. Some people are doing nothing whereas others working at 200% capacity yet the promotions do not reflect that accurately

review_title: Was a great place to work, until management changed
pros: Great people, very knowledgeable about Oracle software, as you would expect. Good levels of communication and information sharing between colleagues.
cons:
A change in practice management precipitated a steep move downhill. A lack of understanding of what is involved in deploying ERP cloud applications led one manager to instruct a consultant to deliver 6 ERP modules single-handedly. Lots of cheap graduate resources were hired, and expected to deliver major projects without adequate training or senior-level oversight.
Advice to Management
Your people are your best asset, treat them well and provide them with adequate support.

review_title: Big company with lots of learning opportunities
cons:
ltant in Bucharest
Recommend
CEO Approval
Business Outlook
Pros
Oracle is a very well structured company, with plenty of growing opportunities. You have a vast array of learning tools available to you, so that you can grow in your career as well as your knowledge. Because of its vast size you are able to switch departments seamlessly as well as expand your career options within the company itself without having to look elsewhere.
Cons
It's a big company with a small heart. As much as may be touted about caring about people, it's painfully obvious when you see how disconnected management is from the workforce. If you come to Oracle knowing that you are simply a number, it'll help you navigate the company much better and understand the many organisational changes that occur.
Advice to Management
I'd advise Senior Management to read Steven Hassan's book on Cults to avoid creating a cult-like atmosphere within Oracle, which has been on the rise. Many unspoken rules often linger within the company which lead many to be unhappy, but afraid to speak out.
Be the first to find this review helpful

pros:
Free access to internal and other trainings
Starting salary was not bad (10 yrs ago)
Good culture
Home office
cons:
Lack of career prospects - depending on the business unit / industry, there is a huge difference between salaries and opportunities. If it is the HSGBU, prepare that you will be stuck in the same position for years without any progress.
Upper management is not necessarily competent, some of them have no clue what their directs are doing.
Advice to Management
People do not want to retire from the same position. Invest in their education and also provide REAL support and opportunities in case they want to stay and move up between departments. Upskilling people and then have them do the same job for the same money is not a real upskilling and is practically nothing... you should listen to your people what are their plans for the future and read those damn appraisals.

pros:
- Great place to learn new things and develop the skills and expertise
- Job itself is intellectually challenging 
- Many resources for studying and self-development
- Nice offices, nice working environment
- Free fruits, coffee and tea
- Nice colleagues
- Sodexo meal vouchers, free Czech/English language courses, 100% pay during the sick leave
- 25 days of vacation
cons:
- There is no annual bonus or annual salary increase, meaning that no matter how many years someone is working for the company, they will have the same salary as on the first day, unless promoted
- Relatively long time to get promoted (it takes 2 years minimum)
- Change of the team or department does not give any uplift
Advice to Management
You have amazing employees in there. Start thinking of their well-being in a long term, and you will keep your motivated and hard-working staff, and stop them from leaving

Many internal apps used for work are old and kludgy, looking like they were written 20 years ago. Others have serious performance issues, which really slow down work. There are two many architects involved in the development of internal tools and procedures, resulting in complex and cumbersome obstacles to the development of the documentation. Big one: almost no raises! If you stay more than five years your compensation not only doesn't grow, you lose ground because of inflation. People quit for this reason.
Advice to Management
How can you seriously think that you can maintain or increase employee retention if you don't address the wage stagnation issue?

and cons

cons:
ltant
5 Feb 2021 - Cloud Engineer 
Recommend
CEO Approval
Business Outlook
Pros
Best in class equipment (Macbook's samsung monitors, etc...etc), free beverages and gym on campus and experience with the latest and future technologies.
Cons
- Extremely hit or miss management. I worked there for 11 months and had 3 managers. 
- Being a large organization, they reorg all the time, which causes roles and territories to get mixed around. 
- Too much information for entry level employees to master. (Other companies such as Salesforce or AWS don't start college grads in these roles for a reason).
Advice to Management
- Be honest about what a "Cloud Engineer" is. Sales Engineering is a great role, but calling it a Cloud (specialization) Engineer role does not sound like sales at all. 
- Don't set the salary the same for all the hubs when COL is much higher in D.C, Boston and Santa Monica then Austin.

ltant in Austin, TX
Recommend
CEO Approval
Business Outlook
Pros
They hire a ton of college graduates, a strategy shared by all smart companies in my opinion. As such, it means they're willing to teach and train, and the investment they make in employees is much appreciated. I learned a lot about technologies that had previously been foreign: database, middleware, infrastructure, on-premises, and cloud solutions. Plus, it also pays well for people who lack experience. Never found it to be a particularly demanding job, and I very very rarely took home work after leaving.
Cons
The other side of hiring young is that many managers are young and often unqualified. They don't seek out input from those who are managed, so if you get a poor manager it means you're likely stuck with them, and their word will hold more weight than yours. Being tied to sales means you're also tied to quotas and other unimportant metrics, many of which are typically outside of your control.

review_title: Poor treatment of employees in this department, get in through another team if you can
pros:
Diverse workplace
Average learning curve
Free refreshments on each floor of the building
cons:
Poor scheduling options
Pay is below average
Advice to Management
Directors in this department are more concerned with keeping people who perform well where they are to keep their own behinds covered instead of rewarding them with growth and further incentive. On one team I know of, the supervisor (who came over from sales and knows nothing about the software or the anything beyond making things look good on paper) was promoted and probably given raises multiple times. Most of the people on the hardworking team beneath her have been stuck in the same spot since before she arrived despite having done more than enough to progress to better things. My advice to management is to acknowledge this position of what it is, a stepping stone job, and reward the people that are making you look good instead of keeping them in the same place simply so that they can continue to do so.
Be the first to find this review helpful

pros:
Pays moderately well
Benefits are good
Many great coworkers
cons:
SMB sales org is not well designed and turnover is extremely high.

A majority of people stay in this role only for the chance at a large deal. Luck is your best bet, as hard work is unlikely to impact customer buying habits for certain product lines. Quotas are set evenly across every territory, and territories are not even.

Few people enjoy the job, and a very large portion of people actively dislike coming to work. The quality of your manager makes a significant impact, and unfortunately many of the managers are disliked by their Sales Reps.

Additionally, people are frequently moved around to different teams, demoted, laid off, or fired.
Advice to Management
Accurately set quotas. Fire managers with high turnover on their team. These employees may produce numbers for a few years, but they scare away talented employees and burn bridges with customers.

review_title: great first job out of college
pros: decent entry level pay, great onboarding program, pretty strong team camaraderie, amazing people, great benefits
cons:
your performance/commission also depends of skill of your manager and luck of your territory (if your have a bad Account Exec, your opportunities will never make it). you have to really fight to get any kind of raise. unless you absolutely LOVE technology and software sales, then the work sucks the life out of you. Also, it is incredible hard to move into a different department other than sales for this role.
Advice to Management
Maybe change up the commission structure for starting BDRs, and enable growth or training so BDRs can learn about other departments. Encourage more team bonding, and focus more on learning and development. But still have to say, I loved most everyone I worked with. Keep at your recruiting and keep at developing superstars.

pros: Overall, the direction the company is moving in is really positive. There's going to be more alignment between product and customer-facing teams and there is a lot of product innovation happening. It's really exciting to see. The healthcare cover is fantastic. It's really really difficult to get fired.
cons:
This is where the hit or miss comes into play. Some managers are fantastic and you'd be really fortunate to be on their team and be mentored by them. Other managers are really toxic and just plain awful. The 401K match and stock purchase plan left a lot to be desired considering the profitability of the company. Stock purchase plan offered a 5% discount, which is something but it could be more generous. The org structure is all over the place; there's little consistency across accounts, making it really difficult to know who to turn to and where responsibilities lie.
Advice to Management
Perform 360 reviews on managers and directors. I was given plenty of feedback, but unless a manager or director asked me for feedback, I didn't have the opportunity to give it. Poor managers cherry pick those to give them year-end evals, so their awful management skills go unnoticed and unimproved. For those way up at the tippy-top, remove the red tape and barriers for people to move teams and roles within the org. We're told attrition is at an all-time high, but then we're hanging on forever to get a transfer; this is pushing us to just look elsewhere.
Be the first to find this review helpful
Helpful
Share
Repor

review_title: Great Company. Great Product. Great People.
pros: For a first job out of college, you can’t ask for anything better. The first month is training and then you go live. There is a major need for NetSuite in the small-medium business sector so it makes outreach a lot easier. Everyone is fresh out of college so there’s a lot of energy and competition. Hands down one of the best sales development programs out there. The entire program is focused on lead generation and talent development. The BDR pay is top notch compared to other companies in the tech industry and the AE pay is significantly more once you get promoted. Like any sales job, it’s challenging at times but I would highly recommend Oracle NetSuite to any students applying for sales jobs in the tech industry.
cons:
At times, the training sessions are unproductive and a waste of time.
Advice to Management
Keep promoting within the BDR program. There’s a lot of talented people that are hungry to be AE’s.

review_title: Oracle Account Manager - Prior Company Bought Out
pros: They encourage employees to work from home. Benefits were decent.
cons:
Former company was bought out and instantly became part of Oracle without much forethought on either end. Oracle is excellent at selling product, but lacks with support. As a result, our team dealt mainly with unhappy customers who no longer had the same essential support from prior company to run their businesses 24/7. While the support infrastructure went south, the support fees climbed, which further upset customers which was understandable and sympathized with them, but not much we were able to do as everything came from corp, which should have been left with our specific team handling that vertical.
Advice to Management
Get to get understand and education yourselves about newly acquired companies, their specific business models and the verticals involved.

pros: Great benefits; overall culture in the Oracle Cloud Infrastructure org of Oracle is community-focused (which encourages team communications and transparency); relatively easy to transfer between teams as desired; options to work remotely, post-COVID; many projects available to work on, so your career can be a bit self-directed by team; a good measure of autonomy.
cons:
Persistent issues with top-down communication and direction; no practical support or training for managers, so many poor ones here; whistleblowers tend to be punished; review and promotion system is very broken (and was skipped entirely in 2020), leading to a lot of resentment and frustration; focus on hiring devs from competitors over hiring quality candidates where needed in the business is also causing resentment and frustration; suffers from the same sexism issues as most of tech (women rarely promoted into leadership, women paid less than their male counterparts); high-level execs seems disconnected from reality and their employees (one recently announced that "cost of living has gone down this year" as justification for no one below a specific managerial level getting COLAs).
Advice to Management
Invest in your current employees through managerial training and support, actively doing something with the mentorship program you created, being vocal about career development from a higher level of leadership, and showing an understanding of where employment gaps need to be filled on teams.
6 people found this review helpful

pros: Oracle has world-class training programs for their salespeople, especially those who join fresh out of college.
cons:
Overworked and underpaid, the Oracle sales floors, once buzzing, are now barren wastelands. Management actively tells you NOT to learn about the product as a salesperson, so you don'tr realize how behind the competition our technologies are. Salespeople are forced to act on a detached management's half-baked ideas, both for sales plays and sales teams, effectively forcing the good talent out when they realize how backwards (or absent) the strategy is. In App sales, we were told to preach collaboration between departments, and how THAT is the key to successful business execution... 3 years later as a salesman, I still couldn't name anyone in Oracle's Marketing department. Bottom line, as an Oracle sales representative, you're forced to lie to the customer, produce results with a failing strategy, and give up any peace of mind/free time when your manager doesn't like your weekly results and makes you stay until 7:30 on a Friday to prove you want your job (without overtime of course!). Management at Oracle likes to push everyone until they're a burnt out, depressed, soggy little shell of the employee they originally hired. To all the college students looking at Class Of, do it, but dont stay more than 1 quarter after you get promoted. The abuse you take in 1 year here is more than anything you'll ever have to deal with at a healthy working environment.
Advice to Management
Pay increases to at least match inflation. Think through your ideas before turning them into teams, and rethink the company management style of "Just put more pressure on them". Thats how you get suicides, not productive employees.

review_title: A fine place to take it slow.
pros: The people you work with are friendly and once you get the hang of the job, it's not awful. It's generally a very relaxed environment so it's very easy to get into a daily rhythm. You get a number of holidays that many companies don't have off. You can get certified in Oracle products for free and they have tuition reimbursement.
cons:
1. The pay is low for the work expected.
2. You don't have much ability to implement change to the products or practices. 
3. There isn't much room to move within the company.
4. Raises are few and far between. New employees straight out of college will come in making more than engineers with years of experience. 
5. The turnover is high.
Advice to Management
You need to push more money to the lower rungs of the company. Oracle doesn't have the "hot young cool" reputation like Google, Facebook, or Salesforce so it's hard to pull in young talent. But when you do, it's hard to keep young talent when they aren't paid what they're worth. High turnover also leads to higher stress since there's fewer people with many years of experience.
2 people found this review helpful
Helpful

review_title: Horrible company with bunch of incompetent leaders
pros: I haven't seen any pros, cons are as follows
cons:
Well here the list goes on

Oracle in general,
1. Not an employee friendly company
2. No open door policy
3. "Transparency" does not exist in their dictionary

Things that I have observed
1. Alarmingly outdated technology
2. Those who are staying here for long time are known for their arrogance as well as stupidity
3. Managers are high paying idiots, they have no clue what's going on in the project, what are the challenges, whether the code is of good quality. They are just bothered about number of code changes getting merged so that they can use it as a trump card of their promotion

4. Managers (onwards) are there just to warm their seats and to shout at their subordinates for no reason, now a days trends are changing, managers are becoming engineering managers. But Oracle managers are happy to remain as good for nothing leeches.

5. No hike or bonus for atleast 2-3 years no matter how much you put.
6. In the end, there is no learning only meaningless slogging
Advice to Management
1. Upskill yourself and help your employees, don't just sit like leeches and eat all money.
2. Its quite evident, you are incompetent, leave your job and sell vegetables, the salary you are drawing can be used to feed 4-5 talented folks.
3. Don't just think about your benefits, sometimes think about the product also.
4. Do some courses on "how to become a good manager", because you guys are clearly good for nothing, incompetent, dumb parasites who are sitting in the company for years and destroying the talent pool

review_title: Good place to start your career, not end it
cons:
ltant in Santa Monica, CA
Recommend
CEO Approval
Business Outlook
Pros
Amazing place to start your career. Beautiful building and an opportunity to live in LA and work near the beach. Your peers are a ton of people your age so the culture is great. You learn a ton of great tech industry and business knowledge and skills but at the end of the day, it's a sales gig. Day after day of cold calls, emails, linkedin messages. Quarter after quarter of demanding quotas, stressful micromanagement tendencies and repetitive trainings.

Overall, it's a great place to get experience in the industry, especially if you want to go into sales. For the 80% of BDCs who don't want to be in sales and never wanted to be in the first place, it's a good name-recognizable place holder on your resume for your next job.
Cons
Work satisfaction often depends heavily on who your manager is (micromanagey, etc)
Lots of pointless activities such as repetitive trainings.
Constant changes. 
Sales jobs.
Advice to Management
Don't be micromanagey. 
If you want to lower turnover, be more open to BDCs switching departments.

ltant 
Recommend
CEO Approval
Business Outlook
Pros
Most co-workers are very friendly
Lots of new hires who try to make a positive difference
Cons
North America Applications leadership doesn't care about talent development, career progression, rewards & recognition and morale within the consulting organization that reports up to NAA.
A serious lack of talent prohibits efficient & effective project management of the consulting engagements to implement the cloud applications
Consulting projects are underestimated, under priced and under staffed with weak project governance. Most projects are in red status. Consultants work tirelessly to make up for the deficiencies and to cover scope creep to keep customers happy.
Application licensing teams whip the consulting organization around by giving short notice on pursuit deadlines, slash estimates, margin & contingency and overpromise on scope & service levels. 
Those same projects are highly marketed within Oracle as success stories.
Promotions from Analyst to Sr. Analyst have been rare (though getting better). Promotions above Sr. Analyst are extremely rare. Salary increases are extremely rare.

cons:
ltant
9 Jan 2021 - Consultant in Toronto, ON
Recommend
CEO Approval
Business Outlook
Pros
- big company so it looks good on your resume
Cons
- terrible culture 
- deceptive leadership 
-abysmal top-down leadership
- 0 perks 
- gave all US consultants raises during COVID both nothing to Canadians
- it took 8 days for the founder to send out an company-wide internal email about BLM (said he is thinking of strategic ways to address the matter and make the company more inclusive only to put an Instagram post up a week or so after the email and call it a day) but only took 12 hours to send out an internal email about DC riots (condemning it)
- never once saw leadership in the office... but they call in every from their ranches and barn in the country
- contradictory leadership
- zero funds to provide WFH tools (desks, monitors, etc)
Advice to Management
- invest more in the employees 
- do a complete overhaul of policies
- bring back graduate tuition assistance or grant programs 
- be innovative

review_title: Has the upside of being a part of the Oracle family; but uses legacy technology
cons:
ltant in Bangalore
Recommend
CEO Approval
Business Outlook
Pros
Falling under the umbrella of Oracle, the organization gives you MNC perks. The Oracle access card can be used at any of the regional offices.
Facilities at Oracle Tech Hub can be availed.
The office interiors and general perks are as good as other MNCs and there are 11 total holidays available in a year.
Cons
They make dry promotions. Bonus is variable, and subject to the business of the region you're working for. Even when your performance remains same, if you shift regions that you're working for, your bonus may be affected.
They majorly use legacy PL/SQL technology to handle Flexcube related things. As a consultant, there isn't much progress in the first two years with the organizations. The tools they use are also pretty outdated.
Be the first to find this review helpful
Helpful

pros: There's a lot of good things Oracle offers. Great benefits. Strong offerings for medical and other insurances. The 401k offerings. Solid coworkers and fun environment.
cons:
Though I was in a "start-up" portion of the company, there was a tremendous amount of mismanagement across the board. From team leaders to higher up, the levels of actual work being completed was minimal with books being cooked and favoritism all across the board. Which is probably why that section was disbanded, but the new direction wasn't any better. No sooner had we crossed into the new fiscal year, than layoffs became necessary. Why it was necessary was above my pay-grade... All I know is they gave little direction or metrics for success towards the end. You can't improve if you don't know the goal.
Advice to Management
Be more transparent. Create success metrics for all departments and teams. Let them prove their worth before summarily dismissing them. Or give them ample time to re-situate themselves in the company instead of the standard two weeks. It can be a great company to work for if the management hires leaders who think more about their product and employees rather than their own bonuses.
Be the first to find this review helpful

Technical Support Management only cared about their metrics. My first manager was good and seemed to care about his team somewhat. My second manager could hardly remember the names of his team members and constantly pointed out mistakes and flaws, very rarely praising a job well done.
Formal training was nonexistent. Employees were required to read manuals and documents on their own for their training.
We were significantly under staffed and over worked, yet they still laid off one third of our team (twice).
Senior management would consistently preach about good customer service, then they would take away all of the tools to provide said service.
Stressful environment. I don't miss it for minute!
Advice to Management
Invest in training your support people so they can provide the kind of service customers expect for the high dollars they spend on their service contracts.

review_title: Oracle great company, but not for everyone
cons:
ltant 
Recommend
CEO Approval
Business Outlook
Pros
Stable job
Proper 9-5 job
Hire really smart people
Very good starting job with a huge branding.
BDC is the first step into doing sales, but can't be stuck in this role for too long.
Take the opportunity to learn about Oracle portfolio. Like it or not, they are one of the biggest corporation and there's a reason why.
A lot of learning platform internally with a lot of helpful teammates.
Huge investment towards the cloud, cutting edge technologies
Great valuable certification from Oracle which is great for any future employment
Cons
Coming from the BDC perspective, the BDC title is actually telemarketing. So don't be too excited thinking you are doing any "business development". Your job is just to pick up phone and call. Not much of a rocket science there. They hire graduates in pretense of learning sales, but you are basically cheap labor to pick up call, as career progression is really difficult here. 

From telemarketing, you basically move to another telemarketing role + sales closure. The BDC is constantly at risk of losing their value since there's not much ROI coming from this business unit, since their job is just demand gen. 

Also there are lots of office politics going on, since everyone needs to keep their job. While doing your job, you need to be able to manage politics as well.
Advice to Management
Be honest to applicants that BDC means telemarketing. Do not have to sugar coat it to sound more fancy than it really is. This will help you filter those who are really meant for the job instead of the constant turnover.
Be the first to find this review helpful

review_title: Don't join Oracle if you want decent money to earn a living
pros: Good training programs, health insurance and intelligent people to work with
cons:
Oracle gives a pay rise to 5% of it's employees every 2 to 3 years. So you can go 10 years and not get a pay rise. There are Engineers that exceed expectations in their performance ratings and yet do not receive a pay increase. Oracle believes you should take pride in working for Oracle rather than the money which is so sad. If you get the chance to join, negotiate a very high salary because you will not get another pay rise if you are luck enough in at least 2 to 3 years.
Advice to Management
Stop being so greedy. Larry and Safra and the senior management make billions. Yet the people at the bottom make peanuts and they don't care.

review_title: I have yet to find a better deal
pros:
- Oracle consist of a lot of acquired startups which absolutely don't conform to the stuffy corporate image Oracle has
- incredible WLB
- above average pay
- legacy groups (DB, MySQL, Java) still have some of the brightest minds in the entire industry
- extremely large scale offers unique opportunities
- remote work
- company paid conferences, training, travel
- D&I is taken seriously
cons:
- Bureaucracy. Yes, every big company has it, and yes, it's worse at Oracle.
- volatility in the cloud org has impeded aspects of critical feature development, and it remains totally uncompetitive
- security are hamstrung by top-down corporate policies that make no sense
- "eat your own dogfood" applies here but Oracle internal products are awful
- no raises. dry promotions, dive & save offers come too late to retain talent
Advice to Management
You need to stop bleeding engineers by properly compensating your US employees outside of OCI, and adopt corporate legal and security policies compatible with a culture of innovation. I have witnessed your posture of legal/security risk aversion cost us multiple 8-figure deals due to the tremendous strain it puts on our ability to act on partnerships in a timely manner, and the chronic failure to innovate induced by this culture poses an existential threat to our business. Retain and empower your ICs.

review_title: Incredible for learning - Poor Treatment of Employees
cons:
ltant in Denver, CO
Recommend
CEO Approval
Business Outlook
Pros
1. Such an incredible place to learn - NetSuite puts a ton of pressure on their entry level analysts to learn and learn fast, I think that if you want a challenge this job will give it to you. You'll be really stressed your first year trying to learn everything and to be a good consultant but the amount you learn in your first year is insurmountable compared to other jobs

2. Very little micro-managing - if you like to take on leadership and do your things yourself NetSuite doesn't micro manage - in fact your manager will probably never even know a fraction of the things you're doing most of the day. Definitely a pro if you don't like to be micro-managed a con if you want to have a relationship with your manager

3. Heavy exposure to many lines of business - depending on what you specialize in, NetSuite provides you great exposure to many different types and kinds of businesses through their "shared resource pool"
Cons
1. Isolating - very little connection between managers/co-workers/project managers. You feel really distant from management and your "manager" doesn't even really know what you're up to unless you're in trouble. Oracle doesn't do anything to help foster a connection between leadership and their employees.

2. Very little work-life balance - expect to work weekends, late nights, and not get paid overtime until after your first year. Your PTO and vacation days are counted against your utilization so basically they inevitably discourage you from using PTO as your utilization is the key metric they look at for promotions. Expect to give your life and soul to NetSuite for your first 2 years if you end up staying that long

3. Over-Utilized and Underpaid - compared to other firms oracle overworks their tenured consultants while consistently underpaying them. You won't get a bonus, you won't get a pay raise until they promote you - it's really corporate and you can't do anything about it (no negotiations, "it's just how it is")

4. Retention - so many people leave and management doesn't do anything to acknowledge the lack of retention
Advice to Management
try just a little harder to increase transparency to your employees... we notice things - just acknowledge the elephant in the room rather than sweeping things under the rug

review_title: When performance does not equate to remuneration gain.
pros: Access to some of the smartest people in the industry, cutting edge technology, working for a company that is helping business change the world for the better
cons:
Change is constant, and sometimes to the detriment of the business as teams interpret the strategy differently and run and operate in different directions. Internal Line of business competition is Oracle's biggest inhibitor.
Career progression can be hindered, new joiners tend to be paid more than legacy employees because of Oracle's limited payrise policies creating large remuneration gaps.
Anecdotally - if you want a pay rise, leave Oracle and return in 12 months time.
Advice to Management
look after the performing folks that have stayed the course and continue to invest in tenured employees

review_title: Good People but hard work will not get you pay raises or promotions
pros: Some groups have good work life balance. Most of leadership are good people and are accessible to all levels. I see more VPs doing hard work in Oracle than any other place I've worked
cons:
No annual pay increases and pay raises and promotions are rare. I've been part of numerous succession plans that are false carrots to get people to step up, work hard and fulfill goals with no reward at the end. I worked with my boss to get one of my employees a promotion. We laid out a set of goals for her and at the end of year she out-performed what was expected but management came back and said they wouldn't reward her for her efforts and I was told if she wanted a promotion she'd need to move roles.

review_title: They lost their interest on employees who have worked more than 4 years
pros: Work-life balance was great. That's it.
cons:
No focal, no RSU, no bonus, no promotion, no work hour flexibilities and no performance reviews. Management lack of technical and management skills to lead teams. They seem to be waiting for their retirement. Internal job rotation punishes employees with no career and monetary growth. Managements also set higher expectation on employees who work there for more than 4 years while offering new hires who have less related working experience same title and higher salaries (Yes, because no salary adjustment ever since). They are only interest in retaining new hires as they think people who work there for over 4 years are pretty much stuck with the team/company. The only way to grow at Oracle is to getting offers from other companies so that they know you are not stuck with them
Advice to Management
Value those who have been contributing at the company for more than 4 years and are willing to actively take challenges and learn new things by volunteering themselves in job rotations within the team/department in the company. They shouldn't be punished with no growth.

Promote those who have technical skills to managers so that they can at least lead the teams with their experiences and decision-making mindset instead of doing nothing on both technical issues and people management and waiting for retirement.

pros: big company benefits, brand name
cons:
lazy tenured people with lots of stock, difficult processes that inhibit client satisfaction, poor training, so many white men egos, and too much name dropping with no one taking ownership
Advice to Management
Gender pay is WAY off. My VP accidentally sent out everyone's salary and the women make $37K less then the men - and, we all do the same job. Fix this across the board and stop defending having a mostly white, male culture. Diversity does not exist and the CEO thinks diversity means whiny women. Don't move people into roles they can't do. This is a major leadership flaw. Stop competing internally - on prem vs. cloud selling into the same account is stupid. Customers disengage with this and marketing needed an overhaul, but no real progress has been seen to date. OCI is the only technology that works, so no wonder there is growth. And, to grow in your career, you have to STAY a long time, wear khakis and have white hair.

review_title: Get NetSuite knowledge and get out - dreams die here
cons:
ltant 
Recommend
CEO Approval
Business Outlook
Pros
Decent benefits, matching for lots of charities, NS ERP is great.
Cons
Constant churn in mgmt, no raises/comp changes regardless of performance, 4 mgrs in 2.5 yrs, only way to get a raise is to leave and come back 12 months later, heard this from multiple people. Seems like there is very much a clique of who's in - they get the spoils. Feels like factory job and just as mind numbing, cannot find a new job fast enough. Everything w/ Oracle is self service so if you have computer issues, good luck. 'Unlimited PTO' is a joke, holidays count against you so anytime not billing is a dinge on your billability. The only reason for 'unlimited PTO' is so they don't have to pay out when you leave. Not allowed to schedule PTO more than 3 months in advance.
Advice to Management
There is no incentive to stay, zero comp changes in 3 yrs. No career opportunity with constant churn in mgmt. My efforts make zero difference in my comp, mgmt only cares about CSAT, no reason to 'go the extra mile'. Unlimited PTO - really? Sounds great, if it were really only true.

10 Dec 2020 - Business Operations Manager in Austin, TX
Recommend
CEO Approval
Business Outlook
Pros
If you find yourself in the "Right" organization within the company, there are many benefits. If you don't, your experience may be vastly different. In some organizations:
- More stable parts of the organization provide a feeling of job security - its common for people to leave and come back a few months/years later
- Lots of opportunity for working across teams and getting exposure to different areas
- Unlimited vacation (not applicable to all orgs and not all countries)
Cons
- It seems that the company is constantly reorganizing, so if you find yourself in a less stable part of the organization, expect to have a new role and new management chain at least every year, if not even more often.
- If you are fortunate enough to be in a more stable part of the company, there is much more security but little room for upward growth and development
- The typical red tape exists, as expected at any mega company of this size
Be the first to find this review helpful

pros: Great technology solutions and innovations
cons:
Old style of management. Too numbers focused. No customer focus. Sell at all cost, even if client does not use solution. Scare and intimidate customers with audits if they don't sign deals.
Advice to Management
Oracle needs to a new management ethic. The only thing that matters here is the number. Focus on people, employees, customers and partners. Stop selling shelfware. Solve customer problems and focus on value for the customer. Stop threatening employees (performance management) and customers (audits) if you want to partner with and get the best out of them. Almost replace all of the middle management layer, they don't challenge global or regional decisions, even when they don't work.

This is probably the worst global company I've ever worked for.

pros: The benefits are decent. People are helpful across the organization.
cons:
Some benefits aren’t accessible to all. Tuition reimbursement for example is marketed when getting recruited but most I talked to had their requests denied. 

Raises are rare to come by. It was explained to me by upper management that it is easier to access the budget for new hires than the budget for raises. Lots of people deserve promotions but my experience showed that the company rather invest in outside talent then retaining current employees. I was told that best way to get a raise is to leave and come back. Company also publicly promotes moving within organization but management made it clear that they did not support that.
Advice to Management
Invest in your people and go to bat for them. Lots of great people leaving the company.

review_title: Solid option but can be stifling
pros: Stable. Decent benefits. Good salaries. Company culture is okay, rather friendly. Would recommend as the first choice if you only care about money, otherwise as a backup option.
cons:
Not OpenSource-friendly to say the least. A lot of bureaucracy. Many modern technologies can't be used. NIH syndrome. Vertical culture. The messages from the management feel like marketing and spam instead of sincere communication with colleagues. It didn't feel like the management had a high level of trust and respect to the employees, compared to some other companies. In general it wasn't too bad, just demotivating, inefficient and sometimes annoying.
Advice to Management
Let your engineers use free software with less bureaucracy. Allow them to contribute to the FOSS community. Don't fight the community, join it and earn respect. Currently "I worked for Oracle" is not a phrase to say proudly in many circumstances.

review_title: Opower management speak negatively about their clients
pros:
