cons:
The most alarming thing about working here is that they are losing clients like crazy and management doesn't realize it's because they are a bunch of patronizing snobs. Primarily all-white management of the same breed, they speak negatively about their utility clients internally, yet assume their clients should stay loyal to them. Clients are dropping like flies primarily due to Management.

Little or no upward mobility unless you are a legacy Opower person. Management promotes themselves every year, but does not promote their own people. Management is also racist and only promotes white employees.

They don't appreciate the stability and breadth that Oracle provides them. Legacy Opower management believe that Oracle is holding them back. Reality check - it's incompetent and stuck up management who are the source of all issues. 

High turnover and no culture to speak of.
Advice to Management
See above.

review_title: No Covid support or pay raises
pros:
- Take my sweet time to give delivery. No one forces to give work on time.
- Used to have work from Home policy, but now every other company has this. So there is no difference now.
cons:
- Oracle does not have any broadband policy for India. So you cannot claim broadband bills.
- No Covid support for getting infrastructure for work from home. Insurance premium is high for additional covid support.
- No pay raise if you have joined above the median in payband. India pay band is very pathetic and lowest among other product companies.
- Not too many team fun activities
- Sodexho food coupons cannot be used outside of Oracle campus. Not even in neighbourhood restuarants or even on swiggy.
Advice to Management
Try to take care of your employees better, so that happy employees contribute better. If you start to restrict employees without giving good pay or benefits, they will also restrict their contributions.

review_title: Great place and stability but depends on the area.
pros:
- The DB org is top-noch, so it is the preferred place to be.
- It is both a pro and con: great friends/peers but a few ego-maniacs too.
- Managers are usually technical, which is great.
- In many teams you can achieve good work-life balance.
- Continuous education funding (they sponsored my Msc!)
- Great stability in your job (is normal to count your time in decades here).
- A lot of diversity in the business units, if you want a change usually you can find it within the company; which is a self-contained universe.
cons:
- Outside of DB org, things vary more and can be less stable.
- Some areas use legacy processes and technology.
- Some areas compete to each other rather than collaborating (same with some peers).
- Depending on the area, you may get stuck with old technology or niche knowledge for many years.
- In some projects, you may have too many meetings with big audiences; which is usually not very productive.
Advice to Management
Try to get a balance between agile and bureaucracy

review_title: Toxic culture VS great salary - what will it be?
pros:
Benefits & compensation
For juniors it's a great place to jump start your career
You will learn a lot.. Especially with regards to stress-resistance, restraint, and tolerance.
Not too male dominated
cons:
Extremely high fluctuations: Typical American hire & fire policies, even in Spain - never assume that just because you're hired within the fiscal year they'll keep you for the next FY.

Toxic work environment: prepare for people you've never dealt with trying to "steal" your compensation on a deal you closed single-handedly.
The company fosters competition between colleagues in a way that is absolutely counterproductive. The worst part is that your clients know that already so forget about building a trusting relationship with them, they know you'll be gone by tomorrow. Never seen that before, but it's common business at this company. That place is full of selfish sharks who will try to manipulate your leads so you don't get to close your deal on your own territory & customer base.

Some of you might say that this is standard in the life of a sales person. It shouldn't be necessary to spend 80% of your time fighting inside of your company and not being able to focus on your clients.
2 people found this review helpful
Helpful

ltant 
Recommend
CEO Approval
Business Outlook
Pros
-Solid work-life balance, very rarely have to work past 5 or 6pm if you are able to manage your tasks
-They throw you on tons of client-facing projects where you are the lead consultant, so it is ultimately a good learning experience
-In depth training program (4 months long)
-Able to work 100% remotely if that is your thing
Cons
-With client facing work comes a lot of draining, unhappy employees, having to juggle lots of these employees at once with limited support from the org can feel isolating 
-Dated physical office 
-Lack of communication with org changes, had lots of people have their job titles and functions changed with very little explanation 
-Upper management disconnected from employees
-Main metric is utilization rates for promotion criteria, do not receive feedback often enough
Advice to Management
Invest in the organizational culture and clearly communicate with your employees.

pros:
- if you have a good manager then you are a lucky one, as in any company.
- Some bonuses for job well done (not monthly)
- meal tickets
- Health insurance
- Oracle employees discounts for some stores/ fitness
- Free platforms to be able to learn
cons:
- salaries do not get raised very often and if they do very little (10% maximum in 2 years). some never did.
- The vacation days are not paid out only if you leave, in rest you are obligated to take them otherwise they get deleted.
- year end/ Christmas bonuses are applicable only for the countries which are obligated by law, in Romania they do not apply.
- the bonuses for job well done , are taxable so from the amount provided actually you receive less even though you have spent more as you need to provide receipts. 
- you do not have any other allowances other than the salary itself, only if you are upper management or you work with with other regions due to late working hours.
- you mainly do overtime to be able to get your tasks done, but if you submit overtime it is not very appreciated ("you are not well organized")even if you do the tasks in some cases for 2-3 people.
- Management prefers to hire people which are "Yes Mam" 
- Some Managers are known for Micro managing . 
- some employees are afraid to speak up due to managers action afterwards. even if it is a problem raised by the employees to the HR regarding a manager nobody acts upon the complains (even in exit forms).
- Nobody asks why people leave so frequently (less than 2 years) - also, nobody cares.
- Some Managers get promoted on the work of their directs or take responsibility as their own accomplishment even if they did not get implicated at all, sometimes even made it harder on their directs to manage that project (as not worthy)...while the directs..you guessed it, get nothing.
- in-house trainings made by people which have no people skills, or are true trainers.
Advice to Management
- understand your directs and appreciate them more
- increase of salaries to the people which they truly want to evolve in the company giving them a raise of 10% in 4 years (while their KPIs are always 4)....it's nothing

review_title: Company doesn't value Marketing, no investment in marketing, no budget & no respect within the organization.
pros: Nice co-workers, good health benefits & insurance.
cons:
Overly political. Not a good place for women or minorities. Poor employee AND customer care. Pays less than other Bay Area employees.
Advice to Management
There are some talented people working here. Unfortunately, politics is the main driver, not quality of work or customers. For this reason, there is high employee turnover (still happening despite the global pandemic) and high customer dissatisfaction . If you work here, use it as a stepping stone to other jobs and don't think of it as a place to stay long. The top executive's political contributions to advance his own agenda are at odds with Oracle's corporate message of diversity & inclusion.

pros: Clean relaxed profession work environment. Some truly talented individuals to learn from.
cons:
So many. Career dead end, corporate politics. Corporate culture stifles initiative, innovation, creativity and inventiveness. Cost of living raises don't really keep up with the cost of living. The odds are that you will be doing the exact same job you was hired for in 5 years without a material meaningful raise. So many layers of middle management all desperate to take credit for any successes big or small, there has to be a seismic event to shake loose tiny crumbs of recognition for the doers.
Advice to Management
Imagine how much more value the shareholders would realize from their investment if Oracle were capable of innovating on a way to reduce the never ending layers of middle management...

review_title: I really wanted to like this job
cons:
ltant 
Recommend
CEO Approval
Business Outlook
Pros
There are lots of opportunity to learn and if you’re motivated enough, and depending on the type of projects you work on, the teams can be great to work with. It’s a nice enough out of college job and with the free certifications, it’s easy to jump over to a partner firm (with much higher pay).
Cons
First off, the middle management seems either incapable or unwilling to actually act towards any change. So what you say to your manager likely won’t go anywhere. The staffing model also needs improvement; the current system leaves several consultants grossly overworked and others without any work. In the past year the culture has almost completely disappeared (even pre covid) in favor of a high turnover rate. They hire almost exclusively college grads for the consultant role and as a result there’s a huge knowledge gap between older and newer consultants, where older consultants don’t have time to train new ones. You’re also encouraged to value utilization over quality. They say it’s a strong 9-5 culture unless you’re in the group of overworked consultants- then it’s however long it takes to get the job done.
Advice to Management
With the current promotion system, there’s little to no incentive to continue high utilization with work. Transparency would also go a long way in improving the culture. With how secretive things are internally, it leads to a lot of speculation and rumors. Also, spend more time taking care of the current consultants vs hiring new ones who are untrained.
2 people found this review helpful

pros: You get to work with others your age out of college in this position. Hopefully you get to work with some solid AE's.
cons:
The management is very under trained and incapable of helping you. They are all clearly there to just collect a paycheck. The CRM is very unorganized and makes your life very difficult. The whole culture of the BDR organization makes you feel like you are being judged on many levels. I felt very uncomfortable being in the office as it wasn't very inclusive and you are treated as just another number. Hard to develop professionally when the management isn't very professional. Your vertical is randomly given to you and this could result in you either being fired or hitting your quota. Some of the industries you will work in are clearly not well thought out and result in everyone majorly struggling and getting ridiculed/called out in front of others. Networking is also strongly discouraged. Not much work life balance either. You will be glued to your laptop for 10 hours a day to be successful.
Advice to Management
Create a collaborative culture rather than pin BDRs against one another. Build the BDRs up rather than making them feel like they are failing. Hire managers who have management experience rather than just sales experience because that doesn't always carry over. Don't act like everything is great and going well when there are clearly some substantial issues.
1 person found this review helpful
Helpful

review_title: Great place to learn, train and move on!
pros:
- Good benefits: Comparable to the rest of the I.T. sector
- Good pay: Great for a first corporate gig.
- Good paid training: Lots of resources to learn everything from Java, Cloud Infrastructure to Sales and Solution Engineering.
cons:
- No Work-Life-Balance (WLB): Depending on your Global Business Unit (GBU). There could be no work life balance and you may not be compensated properly for all the extra hours you work.
- No easy advancement or promotion. Perhaps this is an issue the tech industry as a whole is privy to but you'll have to jump ship to get promoted.
Advice to Management
Promote from within, fully incorporate Global Business Units (GBUs) like NetSuite and other acquisitions.

pros: It's a solid SAAS / IAAS / Tech sales foundation. This is 101 and 201 out of the BDR program and you will learn if you are a right fir for Oracle or if you will find success at most other companies. The Oracle sales model is an esoteric bundling of overlapping teams where it becomes easy to lose sight of the customer unless you're highly collaborative and willing to sell your own interests internally before ever becoming part of true customer relationships. It is difficult to maintain coherence of Oracle's brand ownership but if all the overlapping teams are able to coordinate effectively, they become a deal-making machine. It is all a numbers game, internally and externally. If this type of sales does not suit you, then you can walk onto most other sales roles because of the excellent training and development resources that resemble more of an academy than onboarding.
cons:
Either Oracle's way of doing business works for you, or it does not. If you want autonomous control of being the brand representative for your accounts as you are trained to be, then you will find that in a direct sales role at most other cloud services company.
Advice to Management
Find a way to build out the structure of alignment more clearly. The traditional vertical / horizontal corporate planning structure is executed to a T and runs well on Oracle's own architecture, but sales does not execute in tune to this architecture. Some sort of "Diagonal" or simplified expression of alignment information needs to be built into collaboration tools, this could be done easily on Slack.
Be the first to find this review helpful
Helpful

I think they should reward well their employees.

review_title: Don't work for Oracle if you can afford it. Keep your job or look else where.
pros: The expenses you can charge to your AMEX card. Expensive 5 stars dinners, open bar drinks, travels, shopping, and so much more!
cons:
The culture has declined over time but always been problematic. Oracle is not the type of place that rewards identifying risks and problems. There is a huge emphasis on following the party line and never questioning decisions or paths forward. Top performers are labeled as a troublemaker when they try and warn the organization of customer problems or potential issues with product or approach. And eventually they get let go. It's become like a mafia since new management came from AWS, Microsoft, and Salesforce. 

You either drink the coolaid and shut up, or you can spend your entire career here watching the "yes man" types get ahead.
Advice to Management
RETIRE. If you have been around for 20+ years, it is about time for you to retire. Life is happening outside of Oracle and companies are indeed offering cutting edge technologies which you are clueless about. Stop pretending you are on top of your game and enough talking about the Gartner report for God's sake. It is a 100 years old- just like you.
3 people found this review helpful
Helpful

cons:
ltant in Denver, CO
Recommend
CEO Approval
Business Outlook
Pros
Stable company, good work life balance, mostly great coworkers
Cons
Very cheap - always cutting costs even during great sales years. Very hard to earn promotions or even raises once hired. Expect no more than 3-5% as a top performer, many go years without any adjustments while executives and upper management reap the rewards. You are truly just a number and the company overall doesn't care much for rewarding its employees for good work beyond useless pats on the back.
Advice to Management
Pay your employees better, give promotions when deserved

review_title: A great Place to get your career going
pros: Oracle is a large, but relatively stable company, with a growing line of Cloud computing offerings. Oracle strives to be on the cutting edge of Cloud technology and all sorts of other related software, which is one the reasons that Oracle is an admired tech company.
cons:
Oracle is a notoriously cheap when it comes to paying their employees. It's not uncommon for employees to years without a pay raise, bonus, promo, stock/RSUs, etc. For most functions, Oracle pays far LOWER than the market. Advice: negotiate the highest compensation package possible, as you may not see another increase in pay for awhile.
Advice to Management
Wake up!! Many good employees are leaving Oracle (yes, even in this job market) to go to other tech companies who pay them what they are worth. If you don't stop the practice of not paying hard working/dedicated employees what they should be paid, more will leave and more will go to competitors who pay better, e.g. Amazon AWZ, Google, Salesforce.com, etc. You can't be #1 in the industry with #3 and lower employees. You get what you pay for. Pay your employees fairly!!

review_title: Covid19 seems to have affected even Oracle
pros: I enjoyed working for Oracle for 4 years. It was a pleasant work environment. All of my co-workers were always willing to help in resolving Service Requests. Definitely team players this bunch. Most work was done at office and sometimes was allowed to work from home on occasion, until Covid19 took over and were asked to work from home. Unfortunately in July I was laid off due to a reduction in force.
cons:
During the time I worked at Oracle there were no pay raises. When I came in I negotiated well my salary because I heard that once you joined them no pay raises were granted. Also I requested to work from home due to long distance driving and was not given that benefit until Covid19 work from home was in force.
Advice to Management
Instead of laying off so many during this pandemic I would suggest the CEO and CFO taking a pay cut along with the whole company to keep their employees onboard until this state of emergency is over.

review_title: Lots of freedom but not much to look forward to.
pros: Very remote/WFH culture for many years so a potentially great work/life balance, if you’re not a 24x7 role; good benefits; great employees for the most part; lots of support from mngt/coworkers - when needed
cons:
Rarely a raiseis given or a promotion; not a lot of growth options - even as an employee internal listings/hiring managers/recruiters don’t respond to you; Mngt mostly cares about their numbers to make their bonuses and targets - they mostly don’t care about your growth b/c they are only concerned with advancing themselves and keeping everyone else down; Execs are way out of touch with employees and more concerned with shareholders over employee happiness; so many processes and individual team processes and policies that it can be difficult to get things completed - and directly seen and impacting customers, though they don’t really seem to care about their customers
Advice to Management
Doesn’t matter, they only ask for feedback so they can say they are aware - they don’t care about feedback and they rarely change anything based upon feedback.

review_title: good company although no raises at all
pros:
I. work and life are balance
2. benefit is good.
cons:
1. Our department was completely dismissed this year :(
2. Unfortunately I met a poor manager with "special" style you may never hear : in team one will be chosen to take on double or triple workload than others then there may(yes, may not can) be a small raise every year. Otherwise there will be no raise for several years ！！ For example, considering 3 employees in a team and 10 tasks, usually the assignment would be 3-3-4 but for this manager the assignment would be 2-2-6 or even 1-1-8. I swear I am not kidding at all !! The "chosen" one will stay the same till he left. Nobody knows the reason and manager insisted this was right in his opinion. I saw one guy worked very hard every day that he even had no time for lunch while his peers are pretty free, then in Nov he was told that there was no budget of salary raise. There is no way to object except leave . 
3. The chair is very bad, because of back-ache many employees bought replacement on their own but company prohibit that.
Advice to Management
Generally speaking, Oracle is a wonderful employer. Should think about a more effective way (instead of a yearly survey) to restrain first line manager's unceremonious behavior, otherwise it will greatly and definitely hurt employees' productivities and feeling to Oracle
Be the first to find this review helpful

pros: Stability, Healthcare, 401k, and reputation.
cons:
No advancement.

Review are annual cost of living raises happen never. I went 6 year with great reviews from peers and customers without a single raise. So that is year over year pay cuts.

They clawed back ever benefit, they even demanded you work from home and took back your internet expense....

Money for raises are distributed to you manager, who then can allocate that amount to anybody, with or without merit. So sucking up to the boss is the only way to go. 

The hate their staff a bit more than they hate their customers.

Besides offering no career path they practice ageism, after 20 years of service at 59 years of age I was laid off by HR , with no notice to my manager or the 2 managers above him.

Working with people who's morals are in disagreement with your own is soul sucking. I'm sorry I stayed so long.
Advice to Management
Pointless

review_title: Your personality has to match the culture of this organisation.
pros:
Freedom to execute on individual strategies as long as it shows positive results.
Huge focus on individual success, career promotions are based on proven individual contributions over a period of time not favouritism or nepotism.
If you have a well researched and factual business plan backed up by revenue return then it is possible to get any approval for a project in place.
Self-starters will be very successful.
cons:
Oracle impose a very aggressive and singular focus on driving revenue, to the detriment of customer relationships and CSAT. This approach is more aggressive in regions such as GULF, APAC, MEA. The company struggle to understand the value sales approach and how this relate to improving cloud consumption. The traditional on-prem license sales approach is still inherent in the management culture.
Self-Service culture can drive the most intelligent and committed individuals to become frustrated and ultimately leave.
Be the first to find this review helpful

review_title: not customer and employee centric company
pros:
Big organisation with big budgets, can sponsor whatever makes employees "happy" such as fancy events, kitchen equipment, games, teambuildings.

As a designer, you have plenty of space to experiment. The UIs are really bad, it is easy to make them better. Good for juniours who need to screw up few things first.

You will get a top end equipment such as latest model of macbook, all perriferies you need.
cons:
Culture is terrible. Typical corporate culture even though they try to look like cool team. It is not truth. Problems are fixed with free lunch and then the leaders brag about it for weeks.

There is not enough designers, expect overload of work. 

More then designing you will be business modeling.

Designers are generally not considered on the same level as PMs or DEVs. You will need to build your own position. Not easy for juniors. There is a lot of pushbacks.

Research is not the standard. If you want it, you do it. Do not expect PMs to base their decisions on research. They use gut feeling or middle management advice they do not completely understand.

Middle management is not helpful, they ale a blocker from being fast and agile team. They block things from release because they want things to be 100% ready. They do not like to risk anything.
Advice to Management
Put customers ahead of revenue in your list of priorities.

review_title: Bad to work, great to settle down
pros: Work-life balance cannot be better than this. Less stressful work environment. You'll get more time to learn and experiment stuff
cons:
Pay. Enough said!! Senior management is not very friendly or open. They like to play things the old way too often. Now a days, its all about openness in organisations
Advice to Management
Start looking at your neighbours and pay competitive salaries. 10 years before Oracle was at the peak of its employee attraction, with good developers from top tier colleges and work places wanting to move here. But, in last 8-10 years there has been extremely high brain drain in the company, both at India and HQ. If that doesn't get fixed, and we don't get back to attracting good talent, we'll be done...

review_title: Bad worklive balance, no salary adjustment, fire to hire cheaper new employees
pros: Great Benefits, HR tries their best to improve benefits regularly as pay does not get adjusted, neither is there bonuses even when the company is making lots of profits.
cons:
Do not value employees, and lots of internal politics at the higher management. Typically whoever looses their department gets laid off. Although HR tried their best to encourage internal transfer, the line managers typically refuse to let their direct leave (there is no guarantee that they will get a replacement headcount), and the hiring manager may have instruction not to hire a internal transfer.
Advice to Management
Value your employees. Stop firing and hiring cheaper replacements. Each person you lay off, may no longer be interested to be a customer of Oracle anymore in the future too.

review_title: Difficulties of pivoting from traditional enterprise on-premise software to cloud-based services
pros: Oracle is focused on enterprise business software pivoting to cloud based software services and has invested heavily in cloud for the last 5+ years. Although it is late to the cloud, it should not be discounted as we are still early in cloud based services
cons:
1. Lack of earlier investments in cloud causes urgency in time-to-market of its cloud based services
2. Time-to-market causes short cuts to its engineering fundamentals
3. Top-down approach to engineering innovation - which kills true innovation
4. Pre-mature optimization - too focused on common engineering processes between newly developing / newly developed services, rather than enabling new services to be deployed
Advice to Management
1. Provide more contexts on company goals and translate that to priorities of each division, department, and group (and less micro-management)
2. Remind supporting organization of their duties are to enable the primary product teams how to achieve their goals (not to instead create roadblocks)

review_title: Get ready to get false promises
pros:
Benefits and bonuses 
Competitive
Opportunities for growth
cons:
The culture is awful at NetSuite. Never have been at a company with such a lack of respect for employees. If you’re not performing they don’t care if you have something personal going on they will PIP you and you’ll be on your way out. Favoritism is very apparent, it is what it is. In terms of growth, the company is doing well. However, since there is such favoritism going on, opportunities are limited based on your connection with the leadership and not based on value you will bring or ability to do the job at hand. I’ve seen very qualified employees interview internally for promotions and not get the job because a manager has favorites. If you’re not a favorite, you won’t grow here.
Advice to Management
Starts from the top down, of top leaders don’t start making a culture change, there won’t be one. Care about your employees and their mental health a little more than the ARR you’re needing to close that month. We all have a responsibility to do our job, but you can also be a human being and care for your employees.
Be the first to find this review helpful

pros: Happy with my immediate manager & team; received 2 raises in 4.5 years - very happy with starting pay; great benefits; great people to work with; free beverages; full service cafe with reasonable prices; activities for employees - everything changed for the worse due to COVID-19!
cons:
Due to restructuring, many layoffs & I was one of them - UNhappy about that! I know many people (engineers) complained of not receiving raises for over 5 years - no excuse for that since Oracle is making money & acquiring new businesses. Some folks who had loyally worked for Oracle for 15+ years were laid off - such a shame! Also heard that no raises were given to employees who are promoted - shocked by that!
Advice to Management
In my case, I felt my manager could have done more to retain my employment with Oracle by offering me more responsibility or supporting my employment by helping me to support other executives virtually in other states.

pros: Good Benefits, Generous PTO, Flexible Work Environment
cons:
Senior Management is fragmented and doesn't have a cohesive vision for the company. The vision they do have doesn't get translated well and the average employee has almost no idea how their contribution fits into the big picture. Consequently, there is constant fear regarding the VERY frequent lay off cycle. 1st, 2nd and 3rd line managers have absolutely no input on lay off, raises or bonuses - it's all decided at the Exec level (in a vacuum). The new executive leadership doesn't value expertise or track record -only the bottom line.
Advice to Management
Step back and really evaluate your IT organization as it fits in the the strategic vision for the company, then look for the people in your organization that have proven to have the skills needed and are adaptable - not just the "cool kids."

review_title: Good work/life balance, solid benefits, zero incentives for internal growth
pros: 401k match up to 3%, 5% discount on stock options, really good Kaiser health plan (with free chiropractic), work/life balance is really good and there was always a work from home day before (and many other departments offer it full-time). Middle management is very thoughtful and nice as are most of my co-workers.
cons:
Nearly impossible to get a raise/promotion unless it's been multiple years. No bonus or yearly increase in the 5+ years I've been here. Even with really good annual reviews you will not receive a raise.
Advice to Management
Middle management understands that they are stuck with not being able to incentivize their team and it results in them losing their best contributors to other companies who offer better compensation with at least equal to greater benefits. Upper management needs to change the culture and communicate that the high turnover for most teams is costing the company more and also creating a bad culture of bitter employees. Internal growth is not nurtured and outside hiring is valued much greater as they come in at much higher wages with little to no experience compared to the internal employees.
Be the first to find this review helpful

pros: Oracle is a large company that for the most part takes care of it's employees. In a sales role there is definitely a bit of luck of the draw when initially taking over a territory. However, for the most part there is opportunity to make money if you work hard and do a good job of building relationships with your accounts. Don't buy into the hype of "it's not a good territory so I can't make money" because the person before you that had the territory may not have been good. The group of people I'm currently working for at Oracle are some of the best people I've ever worked for and truly care about their people. Overall it's a good company to work for and allows you to build a resume to move onto other strong companies if that's what you want or move up the ranks within Oracle.
cons:
Coming into Oracle you don't have a choice of who you work for and there is a big difference between the good and bad managers at Oracle. 
Filling open territories isn't always done in the fairest/best manner. For example: you may have someone leave a territory that is a very good one and rather than offer that to a hard working team member that currently doesn't have the best territory they often hand it to a new rep.
Advice to Management
Promote from within if possible and deserved. Recognition of strong performers/performances is critical and seems to have dwindled since we started working remotely. Communication on promotional opportunities could be better.

pros: Possibilities given within Oracle as a corporate
cons:
Limited growth potential within Oracle Digital
Non supporting management
Advice to Management
Management should support and promote more diversity within management team, hardly people manager existent. Only support given is to likeminded people. As much you go for visibility as much you will get heard and supported by management no matter if the skills are really backed up or if its truly just a visibility approach. 
A split between license and cloud business have been made lately which concurs a competition between the reps and managers, however this is wanted and promoted! Management is always requesting for more but in return never gives back, for example 6 months in homeoffice still now allowance given. We are told to put shoeboxes under our laptops to grant ergonomie. 
Salaries, if you are longer with the company salaries are compared to the market not competitive however new hires do get better packages which leads to more senior reps to leave (since promotions are very rare).

review_title: Good overall company but salary hikes is a real problem
pros:
- Good and smart team members
- Awesome work life balance
- Nice and helpful managers
- Almost no micromanagement 
- Team members are generally helpful 
- Leave policies are good and very easy to take leaves
- Products are moving now faster (from last few years) and the focus has shifted to build something new and useful for customer rather than sticking to very old UIs and frameworks.
cons:
- Internal frameworks are used like ADF which are not at all used anywhere else and there is very less documentation around that
- Internal softwares like jdev / ADF are slow and buggy 
- Many products are still built using Java6 which is almost 10+ years old now and they are unable to move to java 8+ because of the messed up dependencies between products.
- Architecture is completely monolith and although they have started moving towards microservices architecture, it is going to take easily 5 -6 years more for them to release a full fledged product.

Let's talk about the worst con of all : Pay and pay struture
- There is no pay limit for a particular role and hence one SE can be paid 6 LPA and other can be paid 16LPA for same role in same team.
- Freshers are paid more than most of the seniors (<~7 yrs), so someone working from last 7 yrs(Proj Leader) will be getting paid less than a IIT fresher(App Engineer).
- There is no hike cycle literally so employees just keep guessing all the time and even managers have no idea about anything.
- No hikes after promotion
- Hikes in general are also low (<10%) that too once in 2 years if you are lucky.
- No Bonus
- No stock for atleast 5 years and the situation can be random, they can give 600 units(~25 L) of RSUs to a fresher and you get nothing even though you are working from last 5 years.
Advice to Management
There is an urgent need to do something about this pay gap and other related issue.
Please start working on streamlining the process.

Someone working from long is usually very good in internal frameworks like ADF/JDEV etc and it takes a lot of time for a new hire to understand these things (atleast 6 months). So it would be best if management think about few people who are brilliant and still working for oracle.

pros: Great product portfolio. Good work like balance especially with children.
cons:
Very cold culture, lack of collaboration on projects. It’s a “get it done but don’t mess up” type of culture. The mid management is hands off in that they want the credit for projects but they don’t want you to try anything new and risk their name being on it. Everything is self service so difficult to build relationships and community within the organization. 
Also, it is hard to be motivated when bonuses and RSU’s are rare compared to other tech companies.
Advice to Management
Incentivize your employees to want to stay at Oracle after being there and contributing for many years for career growth.

cons:

Recommend
CEO Approval
Business Outlook
Pros
Good compensation, stable/well respected company with solid products
Cons
Unless you have an awesome manager like I had, then you are just a number. When Mark Hurd was in charge, the company was NOT very sensitive to employee needs. Prior to Mark’s tenure, it was. Hopefully the culture will heal.
Advice to Management
If you put compensation “sweeteners” like presidents club In the comp plan of a class of employees, then it is very anti-motivational to then exclude that class of employees from participating. It is not smart to “cheap out” on recognizing the contributions of your top 1% of performers.

ohocken, PA
Recommend
CEO Approval
Business Outlook
Pros
Lots of interesting projects, opportunities for go-getters, great group of people, great work-life balance. Lots of opportunities to grow.
Cons
The focal (regular time when raises and promotions happen) gets delayed or canceled in recent years so it's hard to get promoted or even just raises to match inflation even for top performers. Most real talent is forced to leave if they want competitive salaries longer term. Slow to adopt new tech too, but that's not always a bad thing.
Advice to Management
Starting compensation is competitive, but there needs to be more capabilities for managers to give raises or bonuses to engineers. Don't keep skipping focals.

pros: Free drinks in the break room - Except, COVID - so, really, not many. There are *some* good people left, but that is more a reflection of the people than the company.
cons:
Quick to RIF when their "numbers" are not matched. Process adherence is only used asa beating stick with those who are not "pals" with management - the metrics are faked/massaged/fudged to the point of falsehood and irrelevance, yet still used for "business decisions" and to make managers "look good" (I hit my numbers! See? Are you not entertained?). Very shady and unethical. Engineers told to "play in the grey area" on a weekly basis.

If you're looking for real, objective performance reviews on an annual basis or even cost-of-living increases, go elsewhere - the "reviews" are a checkbox exercise for managers, and nothing is invested in the professional growth of a top-talent individual. 

Pay? Right - they pay the minimum - far below the industry average.

Upper-Management Integrity? Nope - they will either obscure the facts or flat-out lie to a customer just to make themselves look better. This is across the boards, all management teams, as if they have a mandate from above their pay grade to do so.

tl;dr - This is where careers go to die. Avoid at all costs.
Advice to Management
Stop playing favorites and politics. Promote, train, and evangelize your top talent as opposed to those who treat everything as a checkbox. Value human capital over falsified numbers and the perception those faked numbers generate at upper levels.

Who am I kidding - Oracle is *not* the kind of operation to actually do something that makes *sense*.

cons:
ltant in Dublin, Dublin
Recommend
CEO Approval
Business Outlook
Pros
It is a springboard

Oracle in CV is great if you want to work in the IT/Tech/Software area.

You can learn the basics for sales.
Cons
The managers were simply incompetent and apart from empty words there was basically only pressure.

The mood was mostly depressed to resigned.

About 80% of the employees have openly engaged in the job search during working hours. 

There was also applause and a lot of joy when someone was able to get a job with another company.

At the beginning of the quarter the people who worked well in the last quarter were awarded. However, most of the time people actively cheated to reach their quarterly target.

Personally, I have had to struggle with sleep problems and my absolutely negative mood in the last months. This was also a reason for change for me. During my time there I started to do a lot of sports to reduce the stress. I have losT about 7-8Kg in the time there.
Advice to Management
Please hire people who are at least a little bit familiar with the topics ERP/software, IT, cloud etc. University dropouts and dazzlers are not the kind of people you can build a good BDG organization on.

This concerns both the management itself and the BDCs.

pros: VERY GOOD AND INTERESTING PRODUCTS AND CONTINUOUS TRAINING
cons:
You compete not just with competence but with other people inside Oracle, and that is not fair that someone from the same Company tries to steel your customer you have been working with and that tdamages the relation with customers.
You cannot built long term relations with customers because each year they change your territory.
Advice to Management
To increase customer´s satisfaction and win customers´loyalty its important to keep a good service and to maintain some continuity in the sales people for at least 2 years. 

If they are changed continuously it doesn´t give a good message to customers because it doesn´t guarantee them they could have a person of trust, to gurantee them the services and the conditions they have bought.

And also it gives the sales people a bad message, because they would be interested not in win customers loyalty but just to win deals to achieve their goals but they don´t feel compromised with customer´s needs and expectations because they know that when the year ends, they will manage a new territory.

And the image of the company would be damaged if the customer realizes that they were only used to achieve some goals.

pros:
- good place to start Software Sales Career
- Pretty great benefits: low cost healthcare, 401k match, Employee stock program (for purchase), etc...
cons:
- Non-competitive pay. I recently have been interviewing other places, and every single one offers a higher base. 
- Boys Club. Not many women make it to Corporate or Senior Account Executive roles. Almost all leadership is men, and they play hard favorites.
- Unattainable quotas. Quota is pretty much a joke in our vertical. I have not hit quota once in my 3 years, and I am still a top half performer on our team of ~34 reps. 
- Our customer base is still growing, but the product is bound to get outshined somewhere down the line. It looks like it is straight out of the 90s.

pros: Competitive salary, good infrastructure (buildings, offices, computers, etc), plenty of paid holidays (more than many I’ve seen others advertise), stock price and dividends are doing good.
cons:
6 years with no pay raise even though annual reviews are top notch. Management at all levels are all “imported talent” that have no clue how to actually motivate and guide people; management by ever changing metrics. Internal reorganization’s and layoffs are the answer to solving all problems regardless of how much burnout it causes.
Advice to Management
Stop rearranging business units and cutting people to shore up the bottom line. Invest in the talent you have starting with the frontline dev and support people. And actually hire managers and directors that know how to manage people, not numbers.

cons:
NetSuite has slowly been losing its "startup" culture since it is slowly being engulfed by Oracle, which is understandable. There is a lot of pressure to do a lot more than what you are responsible for even if it causes burn out.
Advice to Management
Take care of your employees mentally and emotionally. Do not perpetuate the culture of rewarding burn out behavior.

review_title: Just like their products, avoid them
pros:
Pay was competitive 
PTO was fine
cons:
This list could go on indefinitely, the company hired me and relocated me from across the US to work out of Seattle, 7 months later they are doing a company "reorg" and have done massive layoffs including me. What kind of poor insight and planning is this? Most companies have these logistics figured out and layed out to follow, success alone is defined on how well things are thought out and planned. This exact scenario completely describes the future of this company, if you're considering this company. I wish you well.
Advice to Management
plan better, like a lot better.

pros: Good Work-Life Balance. No Major work and can relax a lot.
cons:

Don't spoil the life of ambitious developers by playing cheap tricks like giving promotions regularly and tell them that hikes are based on promoted role and you will get handsome amount for(int i = today to infinity) { next year } . We all know that Oracle is not providing proper hike from top management every year and let the employees know this , so they can mix and match their life expectations and move on if needed. ltant in Columbia, MD
Recommend
CEO Approval
Business Outlook
Pros
100% remote options available to those that prove themselves (otherwise you are on the road), very little micromanaging, can generally work whenever you want as long as you get the project in by deadline, nice equipment
Cons
Pay is lower than market averages, no yearly performance reviews, raises are given at 1-2% of current salary (so once you are locked into a salary you are stuck there), managers rarely know the technology to help out with troubleshooting and customer complaints- only know how to invoice and bill and put pressure on those below them to invoice and bill. Sales team is poorly trained and make the same mistakes when selling equipment and service over and over. Sales, consulting, and support are constantly blaming each other for customer issues instead of working together.
Advice to Management
Pay at or above market value to retain top talent, implement training programs instead of just expecting people to get it, provide more comprehensive support plans for customers instead of just billing them for more consulting hours

pros: Beefy benefits package and lots of small perks. Unlimited time off was amazing. Ability to work from home and some flexibility around working hours. Most team members were great along with direct managers.
cons:
Worst time card system ever. Horrible old, 1990's interface and buggy. Senior level managers have no interest in employee retention, or cultivating straight forward, open relationships. Old school. Overall company talks the talk, but can't walk the walk of "caring" about humans in general. Heavy meeting culture.
Advice to Management
Really needs to work on culture development as a company and top down leadership feels non-existent. Seems like the majority of high salary is made by sales (which also has a very high turn over rate) and I worked with persons who hadn't had a raise in 4 years, but always were told they were doing a great job. Lower managers are very limited in what they can do to help employees.

ltant in Austin, TX
Recommend
CEO Approval
Business Outlook
Pros
Pay pay pay
People, everyone is relatively the same age and have the same amount of experience
Great Corporation experience
Cons
Bonus is contingent on how the company performs, which during covid was sub par
Everyone is kind of in the same boat as far as experience so it doesn't seem like a typical job job
If you don't like corporations then this isn't for you. I did not like the idea but was willing to check it out to see what the deal was and realized I did indeed not want to work for a corporation.

Promotion path is not as clear as stated upon signing but it opens the door to a lot of other opportunities within sales.
Advice to Management
A lot of things are done for office politics reasons. Your brand is very important but there are underlying things done within the company that don't make the company any money but just promote other people's brands that are corporate hierarchy motivated.

review_title: Don't Go Here Unless You are Desperate
pros: Good products, well known brand
cons:
No raises, Ridiculous Targets, Politics, Poor Managers
Advice to Management
Make it clear to people when you hire them what the annual raise process is. Most candidates don't bother to ask and if they do they are given some vague answer about performance. The truth is there is no process for annual raises as Safra Catz believes its a privilege to work for Oracle. That's the main reason people leave - the compensation becomes uncompetitive. Middle management is poor, have no power. My first 15 managers (yes 15) at Oracle were either fired or made redundant. Oracle don't seem to understand that wages need to go up with inflation - but they really understand how to increase targets every year while reducing a salesperson's patch. This dinosaur of a company likes to think they have reinvented themselves for the cloud but in reality it's lipstick on a turkey. They have a group called OWL - Oracle Women's Leadership - Oracle needs to disband it because it's creating victimhood in women before they even start working. Oracle have some amazing people - male and female but OWL is divisive and counter-productive.
1 person found this review helpful
Helpful

 You get max at the time of joining.

review_title: Corporate Politics, Internal Competition, Little Support from Managment
pros: Class of training is extremely thorough and provides good sales foundation. Great way to build professional network. Immediate experience interacting with key executives at customer accounts. Looks good on a resume and provides professional experience.
cons:
Company is structured so there are minimum 10 Oracle reps mapped to the same account, causing a lot of internal competition and conflicting incentives - this ultimately causes a lot of frustration for customers and rarely puts customer interests first. 

Most sales reps have large egos, making collaboration difficult even if you try. Oracle puts a lot of pressure on sales to meet challenging quotas/kpis, so everyone is so busy if you ask for help you're very aware of taking away people's "precious and valuable time". Company culture is similar to 'bro culture' in a college fraternity.

Management asks a lot of their teams in terms of activity, pipeline, closed deals, and additional trainings/projects, but are so overwhelmed themselves they offer reps virtually no support when help is needed. Activity expectations are unrealistic, focusing only on calls when reps have communicated countless times that emails and linkedin are significantly more successful mediums. 

Also, career development is challenging, with managers often keeping employees in roles for a minimum of 12-18 months and discourage employees from networking/exploring next roles before then. No HR support either - in the internal system under 'my designated HR rep' only information is a 1-800 HR support line.
Advice to Management
Provide proper resources/support so reps can deliver on expectations. Offer more career progression support.

review_title: Sustainable, but not worth to stay
cons:
ltant in Taguig
Recommend
CEO Approval
Business Outlook
Pros
Benefits are one of the best out there (I think so).
Work-life balance depends on the project. There are some which requires you to overtime on holidays, rest days, etc.
People around are quite nice.
Cons
I am just working for the company for 2 years. But there are so many to mention that the company should fix on their management.
Very slow career growth. You will not be promoted even if you deserve it.
They will not try to support you on your interest/passion for other domains.
Politics somehow exists. If your PM has a favorite employee, they will not try to recognize you.
They are not investing in their in-house-trained employees, they prefer outsiders.
They are using "OLD" technologies. They do adopt to latest, NOT AT ALL.
Advice to Management
Learn to value your in-house-trained employees.
Recognize those people which are deserving for their talents.
Remove that small "Politics" culture, because if not, it will grow that much.

review_title: This company is not about pay and related benefits
pros:
For most of the teams, the work pressure is lower compared to other contemporary companies.
Management usually is open for new ideas to improve productivity.
Good culture for WFH, though no official policies are present, with a valid case there are usually no questions asked.
cons:
Have no proper logic of pay increase. The increase in pay for a regular employee will never even meet the basic inflation rate. Hugely dependent on the immediate management even for these minimal benefits. Folks usually resort to reducing their performance for the same and company is usually fine with this unless it impacts deliverables very severely.
No pretense of any additional goodies or encouragement for high performers.

Techstack is primitive in most teams. And the struggle is always there for a minor improvement in this.
Advice to Management
Due to the way management is treating pay , this company has began to become just a bargaining chip for prospective employees who just attend interviews here and use the salary for negotiating for a better company. So many brilliant minds have left. Instead of thinking of 1000 unnecessary reasons on why the company is loosing its reputation and reach, concentrate on compensating your employees better and in updating your tech stack.
Be the first to find this review helpful
Helpful

pros: Nothing I can think of at the moment
cons:
Unless you are a Director, you don't get any bonus, stock options, Overtime, but they work you to death, although there is no incentive for working to death. People are always shouting and speaking poorly of others. Use of profanity among leaders is very common. The cafeterias sell overpriced food. Worst place I have ever worked in my life. Unless you are a director, you do not get a company phone but managers expect you to answer your personal phone at all the times, even if that means paying for minutes and data out of your own pocket. These are the reasons Finance departments have very high turnovers. Morale is really low and managers give out the vibe that they do NOT care and if you don't like the way things are, you may leave. There is no recognition, no appreciation. The Finance systems they use are old school. Practically every week, they are coming up with new logics for their Finance planning tools. No technological help when system breaks, and you have to chat with someone in India or in Singapore to get things fixed (which most of the time they do not know how to fix), which in turn, makes you work overtime with no pay. They hire from outside mostly and takes forever to hire people. Not the most talented pool of senior leaders I have worked with. Unlimited PTO is a joke, because you are not allowed to take time off. Your Manager will get upset if you ask for time off and remember they don't pay you extra for not taking time off. Cheapest company I have ever worked for.
Advice to Management
If you don't care about your employees, you must know that your employees should not care about you either.

review_title: If you have experience don't go there
pros:
Well as you can imagine there aren't many if you're an experienced sales rep:

1. The tech is really good especially on cloud 
2. You meet some nice people
3. training

If you're a young sales rep with almost no experience then why not but tell yourself that you can do better. Still it's kind of a good line on the CV.:

But most young people leave after a year because other IT companies in Dublin offer more incentive and have better work policies.

Work life balance is actually pretty good because nobody actually cares.
cons:
Well first of all Oracle is a big machine but with a management strategy that was efficient during the 1900. They invested huge amounts of money in R&D which enabled the company to have amazing tech but they left out everything that's human in that strategy.

You will only be a fish in the endless sea of bureaucracy. 

The com plan is not adapted to our cloud business as we don't have the same volumes as Azure or AWS. 

only 10 to 20% of sales achieve. So if you want to put in a lot of work for crumbs, you're welcome. 

Sales cycle are quite long so if you don't have a good territory don't expect to do a lot of sales here.
Advice to Management
Management and especially top management should start thinking about the well being of their employee and especially on employee attrition as more and more people are leaving the boat ! Especially the talents. 

It's too bad as it could be a great company and it still has the potential to become one but they would need to completely turn everything around.

ltant in London, England, England
Recommend
CEO Approval
Business Outlook
Pros
Autonomy, management leave you to get on with your work with minimal interference. The team are very nice & helpful & will support you in your work whenever needed. The work can be interesting, a lot of very clever and motivated people who are generous with their knowledge. Great opportunities to pursue further education & learn.
Cons
Labyrinthine, the place is huge so its very hard to feel part of something. No room to move around the company (despite what you may be told) - you get stuck in your role indefinitely and hit a ceiling after a few years & there is nothing your direct manager can do (they hit a wall with upper management) . Negotiate hard on entry; pay rises are few and far between - a parsimonious company.
Advice to Management
Try to foster staff and understand what they want to achieve from their jobs. Don't view them as people who will inevitably leave - but as long term investments.

review_title: Good place to learn and bad place to earn
cons:
ltant in Bangalore
Recommend
CEO Approval
Business Outlook
Pros
1. Nice resources to learn.
2. Flexible work time.
3. Other benefits apart from salary.
4. Great team members.
5. You will get opportunities to your potential.
Cons
1. A manager ( all the pros mentioned above can get offset with one bad manager).
2. No team building events.
3. Bad place if you want to earn.
4. There is some thing call Appraisal cycle for every one year but that has nothing to do with focal hike of your annual salary. Hike may come once in 18 months, once in 12 months or it may not come as well.
Advice to Management
It's great to realise that every GBU/region is totally segregated and their management can take up decisions for that specific vertical. But do you not think it is needed to have a definite hike for a specific period?
Also, in the recent townhall, the speaker informed us about how our partner companies were able to implement our products fast and better. It is absolutely because most of those people are your people only and since you are not able to retain them, they moved they there are implementing faster from your partner companies. It's really unfortunate that you don't have managers who are courageous enough to ask their bosses for the welfare of employees.

review_title: A customer centric company does not start from the customers, it starts from the CEO
pros: Some of the best reasons to work for Oracle are you have really great people with a lot of experience, and depending on the team, but generally people are very nice and there is a friendly atmosphere. Great name for your CV, Oracle is one of the best known companies in the world and they have a vast number of resources available to employees. You can move internally to different countries, there are many volunteering opportunities and you can work with some of the best companies as your clients. There is also a lot of learning available, courses and all is paid for by the company. So overall these stand out as the positive.
cons:
There is, unfortunately a toxic culture, this means that you have to sell sell sell at no cost, even if you are selling your customer something that is not needed you will try to push this as this is the style and what is it shown internally. There is little to no room for salary improvement, I have been there for more than 3 years and there is no rise unless you change your job/department completely and even though that would be minimal raise. The company is fragmented and layered, you barely get the customers view to top management because they just wont listen, completely hierarchical.
Advice to Management
As much as some 1st and 2nd line managers might try to help their team, they are tied hands down by management above, so there is little to no improvement unless change starts from the top. A customer centric company does not start from the customers it starts from the CEO

review_title: Smart, bright people working here, but no opportunity for career growth
pros: The colleagues I worked with were some of the best and brightest! Down to earth, hard working individuals always striving to work together and deliver on common goals. Management doesn't micromanage you and trusts you to get your work done. Since there's no hand holding there's also a lot of flexibility so it's important to be self-driven.
cons:
In the 5 years I worked there, I didn't receive a single review even after submitting my self-evaluations. It doesn't really seem to matter though, because raises and bonuses are pretty much nonexistent. I once was rewarded a bonus, but then found out a couple of weeks later the company was revoking everyone's bonus. Sadly, I think a lack of raises is a common thing across the board. Many of my colleagues and superiors that I spoke to had never received a raise. It's a shame because there are so many talented people working there.
Advice to Management
Please value your employees more. People would love the opportunity to grow their careers with you if you'd be willing to invest in the hard work they do.

review_title: Mature organization with well defined roles
pros: Good pay and benefits. You know what you are meant to do in your role. There are well defined processes and procedures. AND there is a culture of constant improvement.
cons:
Be wary of changing company needs as it is always looking out for shareholder value. This leads to macro changes of teams and offices which impact you. Stay informed by talking with your peers.
Reviews have global rules / quotas that make it unfair when everyone on a team is performing really well.
Advice to Management
Give time to your middle managers so they can actually do team development and coaching. A highly templatized review 2 times a year with quotas is only a minimal part of the people management equation.

pros: There are pockets of great culture within different teams, and different lines of business. The training is second to none, and they provide you with so much material. It's not difficult to get recognition if you show your efforts of collaboration and networking throughout the company. Benefits and commission is structure is very good - if you negotiate well for it before you get the job offer. Quarterly team recognitions which helps boost team morale.
cons:
It's stagnated professional development - when you get a job, expect to be in the same role and same pay for a minimum of 3 years unless you threaten to leave (and even then you need to prove that you are invaluable). Managers do provide support, but you need to ensure that you are holding them accountable as well. Very process driven, so it can take weeks to get something done. The brand perception is an outdated grandfather's company, but marketing is trying to change that (which is a feat in itself).
Advice to Management
Reward your employees when they do perform. Managers should be more involved with groundwork instead of redirection. Reduce the processes - you're losing customers and employees out of frustration.

review_title: Bad place to work unless you only care about money
pros: The pay is good, the office is cool, and it's right next to a lot of great lunch spots.
cons:
First off, this job has made me question weather I even want to be a software engineer any more.

This WAS a fantastic place to work when I started. Since then it has just gone steadily downhill. When I started, the team I worked with was great. Smart, motivated people, who would band together to solve very exciting and complex engineering problems. 

When I started, I got the feeling that this was not the typical lean management type shop, and managers really wanted to grow a strong team, and were focused on developer experience, work life balance, and created an exciting environment with lots of good work to go around. 

Today as I write this review, I am counting down the days until my next round of vesting so I can get out of this place like a bat out of hell.

An engineer on my team recently expressed concerns about the ops burden, and an almost complete inability to work on anything other than ops and putting out fires. The response from management was, in not so many words, "tough sh!t." The people that have been hired recently have been producing work of a quality so low, that I honestly am embarrassed to call them my co-workers. The new projects coming down the pipe are depressing, and even those are getting put on hold because we constantly have to put out fires. My manager has been relegated to nothing more than a bearer of bad news, and that is a shame because he is honestly one of the best people I've ever worked with, and someone I have grown to consider a good friend. The code review process that use to be thorough, helpful, and very effective, is consistently being circumvented by cliques of low quality developers who work completely within their own circles. The result is code quality so low that I'm consistently struggling to resist the urge to toss my computer out the window. I recently saw a conversation with one of our veteran engineers, who was trying to wrap his mind around a seemingly poor design decision, to which his only response was to simply leave the chat group. I can only assume this was because he would have otherwise been unable to keep it professional. And our good engineers are so burnt out, that they just don't have the energy to try and correct these problems.

And not least of all, the people that seem to be getting promoted, are the people who focus on getting promoted, and not on doing a good job (with a few exceptions). The people who are more focused on contributing to their own success, rather than contributing to the success of the organization. And that is a shame.

And also, COVID-19 problems negate any of the pros related to the office and its location.

All in all, my recommendation is, don't get sucked in. They may try to sell you on some of the good qualities and core values that we use to have, but in reality, OCI has turned into another mediocre big development shop, and if you're a good engineer looking to solve challenging problems. This is not the place for you. If you want to make money, and climb the corporate ladder, then by all means, apply.
Advice to Management
You can't build a team based on the numbers. It isn't always about efficiency, and you have to build a team based on people. The focus on efficiency, and the OBVIOUS lack of regard for the engineers (which I honestly don't think you realize is so obvious, and is laughable) is opening the flood gates. I expect that any good engineer is planning on getting out as soon ans they've collected their next round of shares. And I know of many engineers who I have spoken with personally that are planning on leaving as soon as they're next round of vesting. I spoke to one engineer who is mere months away from collecting his next round of shares, but doesn't even know if he'll be able to hold out. 

I'm pretty sure it's too late. I think you've already screwed the pooch. But, if you haven't, I suggest dramatically changing the way things are run, and seriously listening to peoples concerns rather than sending the suggestion box directly to the shredder. But like I said, with the code quality dropping so low so fast, I'm pretty sure there is no hope.

In the middle of a pandemic, Oracle has announced the support organization reorganization during which the accounts that have been nurtured for many years are being shifted to a whole new group. Talk about destroying the bottom line, alienating customers and rewarding workers (not). Think timing is coincidental when unemployment is rampant and there is no where to go? What a company.
Advice to Management
Compassion, fairness, accountability and respect for others - walk it don't talk it

review_title: Good experience, terrible management, priorities misguided
pros: Good experience and a great resume builder
cons:
The company has grown too large and doesn't know how to be scaled. Too many bad experiences to count or say here. Company priorities are misguided and technology is outdated while refusing to change. The management cares more that your dashboard is clean and that your dial number is up more than actually selling anything. The rules they put you under are not there to help you, they do nothing but make your job harder than it already is to make management look better. Wastes of time, lack of communication, being treated like a child doing menial tasks in a college class, all while the fake Netsuite culture is being forced on you to make you think its the best company ever.
Advice to Management
Stop adding more and more rules, focus on teaching new hires to sell correctly. Being a good BDR does not make you a good salesman whatsoever. Stop prioritizing cheaters and liars. When entire teams of employees report management listen to them, a few days off doesn't make a terrible manager better. I've worked here for over a year and Ive looked for new jobs every week since I started because of management.

review_title: Great place to work out of college
cons:
ltant in Austin, TX
Recommend
CEO Approval
Business Outlook
Pros
It is a very young environment. There is a lot of colleagues in their 20s so there is a lot of people who can relate to your experience. The pay is great for the work you are doing. If you meet the KPI and your metrics, bonuses every quarter is pretty decent. There is also a lof of resources that the company offers and you can utilize to your advantage.
Cons
Because it is such a big company, it can be very unorganized. The unofficial motto is "the only constant is change" but the changes at times are not implemented well. It can be really frustrating when there is absolutely no consistency for longer than 3 months. Depending on your manager, you might have to really go out of your way to learn something or find other opportunities for job progression.

review_title: Good work-life balance; Internal Politics will make your job 500% harder
pros:
Management stays engaged
Good managers will fight for you
cons:
derable Remote workforce gives flexibility 
Average tenure is high in certain areas because of the decent work-life balance
Cons
* Tension between Field and Inside Sales orgs
* Internal politics slows deals and momentum. ex: you offer customers will take ages to get approved
* Tribal knowledge is key; you must know the right people to get answers to questions
* Competing priorities by teams; renewals / sales are compensated to be against each other
* Internal tools often buggy
* Aging management has old school mentality, ex: still believes in hub-model with butts in seat 
* Management hounds reps to make cold-calls daily to prospects/customers in the Enterprise space (cold-calls don't work anymore)
* You will be tracked on every metric. They fire the highest earners, so beware of hitting your quota for the year or you'll be the next one on the chopping block (C suite makes financial decisions, not smart business decisions)
Advice to Management
Shift the mentality to reward sales reps who bring revenue into the company and empower reps to "own their territory". Ditch the dial-for-dollars mentality at every level. Align field/inside teams through shared compensation model and fix the broken deal cutoff model that was taken from Salesforce.
4 people found this review helpful

review_title: OCI is a Dying Dinosaur with a Hostile Backstabbing Culture
pros: Nobody works very hard at OCI, especially not the engineers and designers. It's like a welfare program for people who couldn't get hired at AWS or Azure. The snacks are pretty good.
cons:
Management is the worst I've ever experienced in my 20+ year tech career. Mid-level to Senior management actively tries to screw over their staff, lies about them in performance reviews, and promotes anyone who surreptitiously complains about their teammates. It's a culture that rewards backstabbing, lying, cheating, and generally anti-social behavior.

OCI is 5-10 years behind every other cloud infrastructure provider in terms of their product offerings and customer value proposition. They're like a dinosaur flailing in a tar pit. Their constant re-orgs and layoffs only hasten the inevitable. Senior management's only plan is to cheat their employees, lie to their faces, and collect enough RSUs to bail out before the stock price tanks once Oracle runs out of cash for stock repurchases (look it up).
Advice to Management
Quit while you have a chance

pros:
Generally top talent throughout the company, so one feels they are a part of an industry-leading team of professionals. 

The Cloud Customer Success organization was generally well equipped with talented support staff and leadership which made our work on the front lines a bit easier.
cons:
Poor compensation management - if Oracle had its' way, and as is often the case, people progress their skills, increasing value delivered and responsibilities year after year, yet they don't get raises. Often promises are made by front line managers and directors which go unfulfilled due to a pervasive culture of not caring for the individual. 

Customer Success org gave far to much responsibility to "class of" young college recruits who are in their first job. A commendable use of staff when other resources are limited, but the absence of "adult supervision" was notable and a real detractor to those experienced staff and leaders who could deliver with the help of this staff. Instead, the focus was on empowering these newbies who have lots of energy but not real skills or experience.

Similarly, there's lots of public and internal marketing of Oracle as an company which cares for its' staff, but little evidence in reality.
Advice to Management
Pay your staff who deliver. Ensure experienced leaders are in control of operational improvement programs, not the newbies alone with limited quality control.
Be the first to find this review helpful
Helpful
Share

review_title: Review from Tech Perspective: Outdated Tech Stack, No Financial Growth but Good Work Life Balance and WFH Culture
pros: Good customers hence good domain knowledge or exposure to domain. Excellent professional culture, which helps in a chilled out work life so good work life balance. Most of the teams are flexible about timings and work from home as well.
cons:
Biggest two cons are: Heavily, massively outdated tech stack and very rare hikes or financial growth. You have to be exceptional to get anywhere near a minimal hike in most of the orgs. Regarding tech stack, don't join oracle if you want to work on hot tech buzz. Oracle products are massively outdated in terms of UX and stuff. Even the tools like version control, ide etc are very specific to Oracle and not what industry uses.
Advice to Management
I know it's a tough ask, but upgrade the stack, hire people lesser in number and better in quality, and see the bigger picture.

pros:
- Flexibility,
- Good work place environment
- This could be seen as good or bad, workload isn't stimulating or challenging but it allows you the freedom to develop other skills / free time.
- Micro-managing isn't part of the company culture or identity, this is a big plus for me.
cons:
- Your salary goes to Oracle to die. There are no annual reviews, no hikes, your starting salary will remain the same for years and years until you decide to leave. They know this, and they're okay with this. I've been told by Directors that Oracle is a learning experience, and you should take that experience elsewhere to get a pay rise. This should be unacceptable, but it's the not-so-secret secret that everyone knows and begrudgingly accepts.
- The freedom you enjoy to develop yourself and how you develop your work, as well as the great environment this creates, which is very important, is also used against you because upper management makes it clear it's their strategy to justify not increasing salaries.
- Because of this, there's some upward mobility because tenured people will leave sooner or later but there's also a big waiting list. If you've got the talent but there's people who have been there for half a decade, waiting for a chance, then tough luck, get in line. There's no clear career path and there's no intention for you to have one.
- HR doesn't exist, unless things get serious. You will never have contact with an HR representative in your tenure at Oracle, barring the starting period, and you should be thankful if you don't because HR is in place to protect the company and only the company.
- Upper management is an absolute old boy's club, completely out of touch. Their strategies are not working for many years now and Oracle is running out of small, profitable companies to buy. It is dying a slow death and they won't be able to afford losing tenured people in the future, or stop ignoring said acquisitions and customers.
Advice to Management
This is a cliche, but listen to your employees and your customers. You need specialists, you need happy customers. It's not hard, Oracle already has a good culture in place but it needs to be expanded to higher management.

pros: Worked with some of the smartest people I've ever met. No paperwork as virtually all forms have been computerised.
cons:
Procedures for everything and you can't scratch your nose without logging into three different systems and following 200 rules.
Advice to Management
Try to improve employee autonomy and let the procedures be guides rather than rules. Also work with users to get the best user experience for the often incredibly badly designed internal systems. Scroll bars within scroll bars is the biggest sin! A holiday form that lets you book 5 days off on a Monday but those days off must all run concurrently on the Monday, to actually get five days off you have to put a 1 in 5 boxes!! And then managers get confused when you revoke a holiday and change a 1 to 0 and then they ask why you're trying to book zero days holiday!!!!!
